Title: Walter L. Gordon, Jr./William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Description.abstract: The approximately 800 photographs in this collection represent the lifelong interest of Los Angeles African American attorney, Walter L. Gordon, in documenting little known aspects of African American history and culture through the first half the 20th century. Los Angeles and the legal profession were plagued by racial discrimination, but these photographs display a range of people, places and institutions who successfully defied society’s limited expectations. Materials include photographs given to Mr. Gordon by California Eagle newspaper publisher Charlotta Bass;  photos Mr. Gordon collected of images of black resorts such as Val Verde; well-known political figures;  sophisticated night life and social club functions; performing artists such as Count Basie, Louis Armstrong and Billie Holiday. Mr. Gordon established his law practice in 1936; he retired in 2004, after nearly seventy years practicing law. In 2002, the entire collection was given to William C. Beverly, Jr., who loaned them to Eighth & Wall (an organization promoting the preservation of the history of the African American community of Los Angeles). In 2010, the collection was donated to UCLA. More information about Eighth & Wall is available here: http://www.eighthandwall.org|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Description.note: Collection of approximately 800 digitized photographs and other items collected by Walter L. Gordon, Jr. and given to William C. Beverly, Jr., who donated the collection to UCLA. Collection includes photos given to Walter by his former boss, Charlotta Bass, publisher of the California Eagle, as well as other photos he collected. Photos largely depict African American social life and family life in 1940s Los Angeles and feature celebrities, athletes, politicians, lawyers, and other notable people of the era.

Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Julian Rainey with a couple at a party, Los Angeles, early 1950s
Description.note: Julian Rainey (left) visited Walter Gordon in Los Angeles, where this photograph was taken. This photograph was taken at a formal party. The couple [in the photo] knew him [Mr. Rainey] in Boston.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Julian Rainey was the first black lawyer to join the legal staff of the city of Boston. Walter Gordon met him while seeking admission to Harvard. He had a Boston accent and acted like a Boston Irishman.
Description.caption: Julian Rainey, Boston, Mass., Lawyer.

Name.subject: George, Arthur|~|Harbin, Suzette|~|Griffin, L'Tanya, $d 1919-1996|~|Hawkins, Judith|~|Holman, Claude W. B.|~|George, Arthur, $c Mrs.|~|Birch, Joe
Subject: Entertainment|~|Lifestyle
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Group of seven partygoers, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: A group at a party in Los Angeles. From left to right: Judith Hawkins, Joe Birch, LaTanya Griffin, Claude Holman, Suzette Harbin, Mrs. Arthur George and Arthur George.
Summary: LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.|~|Suzette Harbin was an actress and the wife of one of Duke Ellington's orchestra members.|~|Judith Hawkins was an intellectual from Buffalo.|~|Claude Holman was an alderman in Chicago.|~|Author George ran a big lottery machine in Buffalo; retired because of the mob taking over.

Subject.conceptTopic: African American women $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Honoré, Beulah, $d 1908-1985|~|McCullough, Liz|~|Scott, Mabel|~|Gibson-Penland, Gertrude, $d 1923-1999|~|King, Leontyne, $d 1905-1976|~|Ball, Hariett
Subject: Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Group of "well-behaved women," Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|A group of well-behaved women; nice, serious girls. Back far left: Gertrude Gipson-Penland. Back second from left: Leontyne King. Back third from left: Beulah Honoré. Second row, second from left (closed-mouth smile): unknown (real estate agent). Second row, fifth from left (young woman under the lamp): Elizabeth McCullough. Front far right: Mabel Scott. Harriet Ball (front row, center in dark dress and dark hat).
Summary: Gertrude Gipson Penland was an  syndicated columnist, editor, nightclub owner, publicist, and civil rights activist. She was a columnist and entertainment editor for the California Eagle and, then, for the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Leontyne King and her husband, Celestus A. King, were influential members of African American society from the 1940s to the 1970s. She was active in a number of business, governmental, religious, and community activities. She was a three-term member of the Los Angeles Public Library Commission, where she worked to get more jobs for black librarians. After being named to the Los Angeles Sentinel's list of best-dressed women for many years, she was retired to their "Hall of Fame."|~|Mabel Bernice Scott was an American gospel music and R&B vocalist. She arrived on the West Coast blues scene in 1942. Mabel is most remembered for her 1948 hits "Elevator Boogie" and "Boogie Woogie Santa Claus."|~|Liz McCullough was a woman who came came to Los Angeles to visit her boyfriend (he had moved from Chicago to L.A. to start a tombstone business).|~|Beulah Honore, a former dancer with the Regalettes in Chicago, and also an interior designer and milliner, was married to Gideon Honore, a member of Duke Ellington's orchestra.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American beauty operators $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Davidson, Dewey D., $d 1898-1981|~|Davidson, Sadie Louise, $d 1905-1980
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Sadie Louise & Dewey Davidson, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Sadie Louise Davidson was a hairstylist who founded the Hair Stylist Guild, and who became the first African American member of the State Board of Cosmetology Advisory Committee. She was also active in many groups, such as the Urban League and NAACP, and helped found the Alpha Wives Auxiliary. She died in 1980, survived by her husband, Dewey D. Davidson.|~|Dewey Daniel Davidson was a prominent African American businessman in Los Angeles, proprietor of the largest mercantile store west of Chicago. He was also very active in the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity, serving for some years as the regional director. He was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma, which lead some to call him by the nickname "T-Town." He was the husband of Sadie Louise Davidson.

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Mye Haddox, Beulah Honoré, Harold Summers, and Walter L. Gordon, Jr., Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Mye Haddox, Beulah Honoré, Harold Summers, Walter L. Gordon, Jr.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Mye Haddox was a physician from Shreveport, Louisiana.|~|Harold Summers was married to Reverdia Woods Summers, the daughter of Hattie and Tim Woods. She died in 1935, soon after they married, leaving an infant daughter.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr. was an attorney in Los Angeles.|~|Beulah Honoré, a former dancer with the Regalettes in Chicago, and also an interior designer and milliner, was married to Gideon Honoré, a member of Duke Ellington's orchestra.|~|Charles A. Williams is documented as a photographer from Oklahoma, practicing in Los Angeles and married to Yoshi Kuwahara in the 1948 edition of Negro Who's Who in California. It also states that he earned the title "Charles of Avalon" while working at the Avalon Studios, the largest Negro owned studio on the Pacific Coast, and that he had photographed for the Pittsburgh Courier, Pacific Coast Edition; the California Eagle Staff and the Los Angeles Sentinel. His obituary in the Sentinel reports his activities in the public relations profession, ultimately becoming the Chairman of Public Relations International.
Description.caption: Photographer's logo in the lower right corner: "Charles of Avalon"

Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Mr. & Mrs. Spencer Browne, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Spencer James Browne was born and raised in 1904 in Texas, and later attended Howard University. He was a successful barber, opening his first shop on Central Avenue in 1932, and his second shop on Western in the late 1950s. He also opened a restaurant in Santa Ana in 1943. He married Bettye Maria Horace in 1954.

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Yvonne Shelton and Katherine Alexander, Los Angeles, 1940s.
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R: Yvonne Shelton with older sister Katherine Alexander.
Summary: Yvonne Shelton was a secretary who worked for Walter L. Gordon, Jr. for a number of years. She and sister Katherine Alexandern became bail bonds agents. Together they ran the Shelton Bail Bonds Co., and were the first black women licensed to do so in California.|~|Katherine "Kat" Alexander (née Catherine Porter) started out as a secretary for Walter L. Gordon, Jr. She and sister Yvonne Shelton became bail bonds agents. Together they ran the Shelton Bail Bonds Co., and were the first black women licensed to do so in California. Katherine was also an avid bowler. She passed away in 2000 at age 80.

Name.subject: Heywood, Eddie, $d 1915-1989|~|Goodrich, Jim, $d 1918-1988|~|Washington, Leon H., $c Jr. $q (Leon Harold), $d 1907-1974|~|Cole, Louis V., $d 1901-1974
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Jim Goodrich (?), Leon Washington, Eddie Heywood, and Louie Cole, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Jim Goodrich is the likely identity of the man standing on the far left. Leon Washington is the second man from the left (in army uniform). Eddie Heywood is second from the right (in checked jacket), and Louie Cole is on the far right. The two women in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Louis "Louie" V. Cole began his career as a newspaper reporter for the Sentinel and became a civic leader of South Central Los Angeles. He dubbed himself the "Mayor of Central Avenue."|~|Leon Washington, Jr. was the founder and publisher of the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Eddie Heywood was a jazz pianist, arranger and bandleader.|~|Jim (James Russell) Goodrich had a rich and varied journalism career. He obtained a journalism degree from the University of Illinois, and earned two masters degrees from UCLA: in journalism and political science. He was an urban affairs reporter for the Press-Telegram (in Long Beach), and an assistant director of information and reseatch for the Joint Center of Political Studies in Washington D.C.. He was with John son Publications for more than 10 years where he was, at various times, Hollywood editor and associate editor of Ebony magazine and West Coast Bureau chief for Jet magazine. He was the public relationist for Sammy Davis Jr. and, afterwards, as an editor at the Los Angeles Sentinel (1966-67).  He went on to teach at Harbor College, UCLA, and UC  Irvine, then became the director of the Mass Media Program at Central Washington University in Washington state.

Name.subject: Vann, Robert L., $d 1879-1940|~|Le Gon, Jeni, $d 1916-2012
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Robert Lee Vann and Jeni Le Gon, 1930s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Jeni LeGon (also spelled Le Gon, Ligon, and Lygon) was born in Chicago, Illinois, growing up in its "Black Belt." By the time she was 13, she had successfully auditioned for the Count Basie Orchestra's chorus line. She was the first black woman to sign an extended contract with MGM, and danced in 24 films. She also worked as an actress and dance instructor, and has received a number of honors for her contributions to the arts.|~|Robert L. Vann was the legal counsel for the African American newspaper, the Pittsburgh Courier, and after 1910 he also became its publisher and editor. Under his leadership, the paper became one of the black newspapers with the highest circulation in the United States. He was also an attorney. Vann died in 1940.

Towles had a successful medical practice in Los Angeles and was the medical director of Golden State Mutual Life frmo 1925-1957, and a vice president begining in 1945.|~|Dr. N. Curtis King was a physician who founded the Rose Netta Hospital in Los Angeles. It was known for having an interracial staff, and the first interracial blood bank, established by the Red Cross in 1942. Dr. King was also head of the Los Angeles Venereal Clinic and several other clinics.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Name.subject: Boyd, Mildred, $d 1909-
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Mildred Boyd, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Mildred Boyd was an actress and dancer.  She began her entertainment career in the 1920s as a chorus girl at popular black nightclubs in Los Angeles. She later appeared in movies in which she often portrayed the role of the maid. Later in her career she was able to play different roles and showcase her acting and dancing talents in race films. She retired from entertainment in the 1950s.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American politicians|~|African American judges|~|African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles
Name.subject: Miller, Loren|~|Broady, Earl C., $d 1904-1992|~|Gordon, Walter L., $c Jr., $d 1908-2012|~|Smith, Sherman W., $c Sr., $d 1922-2003 |~|Hudson, Elbert T., $d 1921-2017|~|Carroll, Roscoe|~|Burke, Yvonne Brathwaite
Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Birthday Party for attorney Curtis Taylor, at the Broady residence, Beverly Hills, 1965
Description.note: Photograph taken at the home of Earl C. Broady.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Gathered around a dining table (L to R): standing and bent over to speak with someone (and wearing glasses): Walter L. Gordon, listening to Gordon (wearing a vest): Sherman W. Smith, woman in center: Yvonne Brathwaite Burke, standing behind Burke: Earl C. Broady, seated to the right of Burke: Elbert T. Hudson, Seated on the right of Hudson: Loren Miller, standing on the right: Roscoe Carroll|~|The party was reported in a photo spread in the Los Angeles Sentinel, "CURTIS TAYLOR CELEBRATES," 30 Dec. 1965: C.
Summary: Loren Miller was an attorney in the 1940s. He later became a California Superior Court Justice in Los Angeles County. Miller was known for his work fighting for equal access to housing and education. He was also the editor of the California Eagle after Charlotta Bass.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr. was an African American attorney in Los Angeles.|~|Yvonne Brathwaite Burke is a politician from Los Angeles who served as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives (1973-1979) and as a member of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors (1979-1980; 1992-2008).|~|Roscoe C. Carroll was an attorney and a Los Angeles civic leader. He was preseident of the Langston Law Club.|~|Earl C. Broady started his career as a janitor and became a judge on the Los Angeles County Superior Court.|~|Sherman W. Smith Sr. was a municipal and superior court judge in Los Angeles during the 1960s and 1975, retiring in 1975.|~|Elbert T. Hudson was the son of the civil rights leader H. Claude Hudson. He graduated from UCLA and received his law degree from Loyola University. He was a fighter pilot with the Tuskegee Airmen during World War II. He was the first African American to be named president of the LosAngeles Police Commission in 1966 and took the position as head of the L.A. chapter of the NAACP in 1971. In 1972, he took over the Broadway Federal Bank, founded by his Father. Under his guidance, the bank supported growth in minority neighborhoods.
Description.caption: On back of photograph: To: Walter Gordon; From: District Attorney Evelle J. Younger; Photo by: Lt. Walter Morgan, District Attorney's aide; Date: 12-16-1965; Place: Broady Residence [1003 Benedict Canyon Dr., Beverly Hills]; Occasion: Taylor Party

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: Awards|~|African American golfers
Name.subject: Jefferson, Edwin, $d 1905-1989|~|Houston, Norman B. $q (Norman Benjamin), $d 1923-2005|~|Johnson, Ivan J., $c III, $d 1903-1975
Subject: Events|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Norman O. Houston, Edwin Jefferson, and Ivan J. Johnson III at a golf awards ceremony, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R, facing camera: Norman Houston, two unidentified men, Edwin Jefferson, Ivan J. Johnson III.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Men at a golf award ceremony (L to R): Norman B. Houston, two unidentified men holding trophies, Edwin Jefferson, and Ivan J. Johnson III. An unidentified man holds the base of a microphone.
Summary: Norman O. Houston was one of the first African Americans to earn a varsity letter in football at UC Berkeley. He graduated from UCLA and became an executive with the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company. He was appointed president of the Los Angeles NAACP in 1964.  He participated in the 1965 Selma, Alabama March. He was Deputy Assistant Secretary for Administration, U. S. Department of Health, Education and Welfare during the Nixon adminisatration 1971-1973.|~|Ivan J. Johnson III was a Los Angeles attorney. He was one of the first African Americans to letter in track at USC and UC Berkeley. He was a charter member of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity. Shortly before his death, he was honored by the Langston Law Club as the dean of  local attorneys.|~|Edwin L. Jefferson was the first African American judge west of the Mississippi River, appointed to the Los Angeles Municipal Court (1941), the Los Angeles County Superior Court (1949), and the 2nd District Court of Appeal (1961).

Name.subject: Williams, Brother|~|Chapman, Aristide|~|Cadrez, Florence, $d d. 1985|~|Lomax, Almena
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Brother Williams, Almena Lomax, Florence Cadrez and Aristide Chapman, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Henry "Brother" Williams, Almena (Davis) Lomax, Florence Cadrez, Aristide Chapman.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Aristide Chapman was the lover of Henry "Brother" Williams.|~|Florence "Tiny" Cadrez (also known as Cadrez Brantley) was a well-respected musician from Los Angeles. For many years, she served as the Secretary of the Netro Musicians Union (Local 767) on Central Avenue. Later, when that union integrated, she served as the Secretary for the merged Local 47.  She was also the first President of the local National Association of Negro Musicians, later serving as its treasurer for many years. She died in 1985.|~|Almena Lomax was born Hallie Almena Davis on July 23, 1915, in Galveston, Texas. She became a veteran journalist and a civil rights activist in Los Angeles, working first at the California Eagle and eventually starting the Los Angeles Tribune. This is where she met her husband, Lucius W. Lomax, Jr., who she married in 1949. Her activism started early; in 1935, she and a group of African American students at Los Angeles City College founded the James Weldon Johnson club "to further the study and advances of Negro students." In 1946, she won the first Wendell L. Willkie award for Negro journalism in the 1940s, and covered civil rights movement in the South during the 1950s and 1960s. Later, Governor Ronald Reagan named her to the state's Coordinating Council for Higher Education. She died on March 25, 2011, at the age of 95.|~|Henry "Brother" Williams was an openly gay man (his lover was Aristide Chapman) who operated the Brother's Rendezvous underground club.

Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Following a career as a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles, Goodwin (Goodie) Jess Knight was Lieutenant Governor of California from 1946 to 1953, and Governor of California from 1953 to 1959.
Description.caption: Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s inscription: "Always called me '[illegible] Taylor' - always asked about Charlie Matthews, whose indifference caused Goodwin Knight to appoint David Williams to Municipal Court when originally he preferred Charles Matthews. Matthews was by nature arrogant and distant. Williams then went on to [illegible] a Federal judge."|~|Knight's inscription: "To Walter Gordon, with kindest regards. Governor Goodwin J. Knight."

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American physicians $z Louisiana $z Shreveport|~|African American physicians $z Washington (D.C.)
Name.subject: McCullough, Liz|~|Gordon, Walter L., $c Jr., $d 1908-2012|~|Goodloe, William Andrew, $d 1894-1973|~|Haddox, Mye, $d 1896-1966|~|Goodloe, Juanita Anne Jones, $d 1915-2016
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: William Goodloe, Juanita Goodloe, Walter Gordon, Jr., Liz McCullough, and Mye Haddox in Los Angeles, circa 1951
Description.note: Left to right: Dr. William A. Goodloe, Juanita Goodloe, Walter Gordon, Jr., Liz McCullough, Mye Haddox.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr.: "Now these were some hot runners. This man [on left] is Dr. Goodloe, lived in Washington DC. He had a yacht. He was an abortionist; all the congressmen used him. Woman to his right was a similar situation to Ethel [Gordon], on chorus line at Billy Rose’s club. This was a black gal, called high yellow. ... In the middle is me. To the right is Lizzy Putnam (Chicago) [a later interview corrected her name to Liz McCullough]. These are hot flyers. Here’s the disgruntled husband. His name is Mye Hubbard [i.e. Haddox]. He was well known in Shreveport Louisiana. His office must have a photograph section, because people would write me to say they’d seen my photo on his office wall. It was like a clique, we all knew each other. You can look at them and tell they were high rollers. Goodloe got sent to the penitentiary. As a matter of fact, he came out here on a kind of sojourn and when he went back he was supposed to go. This was right before that. This one, look at that chin. His wife… He was a worried husband. Hubbard’s wife, not in photo, she had her own coterie of friends and he didn’t like it. He’s half mad in this photograph, doesn’t like the company he’s keeping. This was taken at my office, I believe. Liz Putnam was just a visitor. Hubbard’s wife left him out here, when he went back he went by himself."|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Dr. William Goodloe was a physician from Washington D.C. who later served more than 2 years in prison for performing an abortion, as well as obstructing justice and bribery charges.|~|Juanita Goodloe was the wife of Dr. William A. Goodloe. She was an ex-chorus girl with Ethel Sissle Gordon, Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s wife.|~|Liz McCullough came to Los Angeles to visit her boyfriend (he had moved from Chicago to L.A. to start a tombstone business).|~|Mye Haddox was a physician from Shreveport, Louisiana.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr. was an African American attorney in Los Angeles.

Name.subject: Davidson, Dewey D., $d 1898-1981|~|Davidson, Sadie Louise, $d 1905-1980
Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Sadie Louise and Dewey D. Davidson at a dance, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Sadie Louise Davidson was a hairstylist who founded the Hair Stylist Guild, and who became the first African American member of the State Board of Cosmetology Advisory Committee. She was also active in many groups, such as the Urban League and NAACP, and helped found the Alpha Wives Auxiliary. She died in 1980, survived by her husband, Dewey D. Davidson.|~|Dewey Daniel Davidson was a prominent African American businessman in Los Angeles, proprietor of the largest mercantile store west of Chicago. He was also very active in the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity, serving for some years as the regional director. Some called him by the nickname "T-Town." He was the husband of Sadie Louise Davidson.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American boxers $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American actors $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Chase, Jack, $d 1917-1972|~|Randolph, Lillian, $d 1898-1980
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Jack Chase and Lillian Randolph (Chase), Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Boxer Jack Chase and his wife, actress Lillian Randolph, and the couple on the right of the photograph. The man and woman to the left are unidentified.
Summary: Lillian Randolph (later Lillian Randolph Chase) was an African American radio, television and film actress, as well as a singer. She was born in Knoxville, Tennessee, the younger sister of Amanda Randolph (who went on to become an actress). Lillian's best known role was the maid Birdie Lee Coggins on the Great Gildersleeve, which began as a radio program and moved to television. In the 1940s, she and her husband, boxer Jack Chase, purchased a home in the "Sugar Hill" district (West Adams), but could not move in because of restrictive racial covenants. The US Supreme Court declared such covenants unconstitutional in 1948.|~|Jack Chase was a West Coast fighter.

Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American judges $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Sherman, Jimmy|~|Sissle, Ethel|~|King, Leontyne, $d 1905-1976
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Leontyne King, Jimmy Sherman, and Ethel (Sissle) Gordon, Los Angeles, 1950s
Description.note: L to R: Leontyne King, Jimmy Sherman, Ethel (Sissle) Gordon.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Leontyne King was a native of Chicago, who moved to Los Angeles in 1938 with her husband, Celes King Jr. She was a three-term member of the Los Angeles Public Library Commission, where she worked to get more jobs for black librarians. She was also active in a number of business, governmental, religious, and community activities. She and her husband were influential members of African American society from the 1940s to the 1970s. She was also known for her fashion sense. After being named to the Los Angeles Sentinel's list of best-dressed women for many years, she was eventually retired to their "Hall of Fame." She died in 1976.|~|Ethel Sissle (1915-1984) was maried to the band leader Noble Sissle, and later to Walter L. Gordon, Jr.|~|Jimmy Sherman was the pianist with The Charioteers.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: Poets, American $y 20th century|~|Tap dancers $z United States
Name.subject: Johnson, Mae, $d 1916-1999|~|Key, Alyce, $d 1911-2010|~|Nugent, Pete, $d 1909-1973|~|Atkins, Cholly|~|Coles, Honi, $d 1911-1992
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Dancers Charles "Honi" Coles, Charles "Cholly" Atkins, Mae Johnson, Alyce Key, and Pete Nugent, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The man at the far right of the photo was identified by Mr. Gordon as Langston Hughes; however, there is a handwritten caption identifying him as Peter Nugent Deacon(?).|~|At table, left to right: Charles "Cholly" Atkins, Charles "Hone" Coles, Mae Johnson, unidentified woman, and Pete Nugent. Alyce Key is standing behind the couple at the piano, with a man's hand resting on her shoulder. Atkins and Coles, preeminent tap dancers, performed together for nineteen years, starting in 1940. Atkins was an expert wing dancer, while Coles's specialty was precision.
Summary: Charles "Honi" Coles was an American actor and tap dancer known for his extraordinary elegance and technical precision. He learned to dance on the streets of Philadelphia and went on to a career on stage in vaudeville and the concert world, in film, and on television. He served as president of the Negro Actors Guild and was at the forefront of the tap revival starting in the early 1970s. He brought tap to the world of concert dance with his performance in the Joffrey Ballet production of Agnes De Mille's "Conversations on the Dance", in 1978. In 1983 he received the Tony Award, Fred Astaire Award, and Drama Desk Award for best featured actor and dancer in a musical for the Broadway hit, My One and Only.|~|Gary Lambert “Pete” Nugent was a preeminent tap dancer in the class act tradition. In the 1930s he was a member of the act of “Pete, Peaches and Duke,” performing in venues such as the Cotton Club. After that he had a solo act “Public Tapper, Number One”.  During World War II he spent his military service touring in Irving Berlin’s show This is the Army. Although Nugent considered himself a tap dancer first and foremost, he preferred “all body motion and no tap”, rather than “all tap and no body motion”. Later, Pete teamed up with Charles “Honi” Coles and opened a dance studio in NYC with called “Dance Craft.” He also performed with Coles in “A History of Tap Dance and its Relationship to Jazz” at the  Newport Jazz Festival, which brought tap back into the public eye.|~|Alice (Alyce) Key was a Los Angeles dancer who later became a journalist, community activist, and political leader.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.|~|Charles “Cholly” Atkins (1913–2003) was an American jazz tap dancer and vaudeville performer, who later became noted as the house choreographer for the various artists on the Motown label. (Wikipedia)

Name.subject: Horne, Lena|~|Nash, Luvenia, $d 1901-1974|~|Luvenia Nash Singers|~|Boone, Elise
Subject: People|~|Arts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Lena Horne and the Luvenia Nash Singers, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Lena Horne (right) and Luvenia Nash (left) are shaking hands in the center of the photo. According to Walter Gordon, the woman standing in the first row (2nd from the right) ran a beauty parlor. She is probably Elise Boone, a beautician who is identified as a member of the Luvenia Nash Singers in this article: "Beautician of the Week," Los Angeles Sentinel, 22 Apr. 1954: C5.
Summary: Luvenia Harper Nash founded and directed the Luvenia Nash Singers, a gospel group. Nash attended the University of Southern California for four years, and then studied at the National Academy of Music in New York City, receiving a Certificate of Teaching. She taught piano and pipe organ, and was an accompanist for such artists as Clarence Cameron White, Florence Cole Talbert, Bell Salter Tyler, Julian Oliver, Estelle Slater Jackson and Edna Heard.|~|Lena Horne was an American jazz and pop singer, dancer and actress, and civil rights activist.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles
Name.subject: Ramsey, George A. $q (George Alvetta), $d 1889-1963  |~|Townsend, Vince Monroe, $c Jr., $d 1906-1997
Subject: People|~|Legal
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Attorney Vince Monroe Townsend celebrating a successful lawsuit against the Edison Company, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R: Vince Townsend is 4th from the left, carrying a briefcase. At the far left is George Ramsey (possibly). The other men are unidentified. Plaintiffs are pictured with the checks Edison issued to them as settlement.
Summary: Vince Monroe Townsend, Jr. was an attorney. Admitted to the California Bar in 1943, he was an advocate for abolishing restrictive covenants for minority groups in residential areas inthe late 1940s. From about 1947 to about 1965, he ran for political office at the city and State levels several times. Affiliated with the Republican Party starting in 1956, he returned to the Democratic Party in 1966.  As of 1966, he was a Los Angeles County public defender. In 1987 he was a judge pro tempore in the Inglewood Municipal Court.|~|George Ramsey ran a racetrack in Tijuana with his brothers.

Name.subject: Birch, Maceo, $d d.1980|~|Black, Carmelita Henrietta Lomax, $d 1913-1998|~|Smith, Bernyce Eblon|~|Tate, George, $c elevator operator|~|Smith, Leon
Subject: Events|~|Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Wedding reception for Bernyce and Leon Smith in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The woman standing 2nd from the left was identified in another photo as a childhood friend of attorney Jesse Mann.|~|Maceo Birch is seated on the floor at the front of the group. George Tate is right behind him. Leon Smith and Bernyce "Bernie" Eblon Smith are standing, 5th and 6th from the left (this is possibly their wedding reception). Carmelita Lomax is 3rd from the left. The man on the far right was identified as Hobart (full name unknown), the stepfather of bride Bernyce Eblon Smith.
Summary: Leon Smith was a Sentinel journalist.|~|Bernyce "Bernie" Eblon Smith was the wife of Sentinel journalist Leon Smith.|~|Maceo Birch was born in Kansas City, Missouri, and earned a Pharmacy degree from Howard University. He ran a drugstore in Kansas City during the Depression, but went on to a long career in entertainment, managing acts such as Count Basie, Ratha Hines, and Louis Jordan's Orchestra. He also ran Kansas City's Blue Room (at Street's Hotel), Jack's Place in New York city, and Ben Waller's Enterprises in Los Angeles. In 1940, he became the first African American to hold an executive position with the Music Corporation of America.|~|Carmelita Lomaz is listed as a waitress in the 1940 Census.

Title: Group of well-dressed, well-known women, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R, first row: Lil Hammond, Regina Moore, Louise Beavers, Dorothy Mundy (with mole on face), unidentified woman (in black dress). Leontyne King (wearing printed dress, behind Dorothy Mundy). L to R, second row: an unidentified woman, Hazel Washington, Cassie Harris (wearing light-colored hat), Mildred Reed (with dark hair piece), and Bea (Beatrice) DeVaughan.  L to R, back row: Gwendolyn Russell and an unidentified woman.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Dorothy Mundy was married to arranger Jimmy Mundy.|~|Regina Moore was married to Clarence Moore, proprietor of Central Avenue nightclubs like the Last Round and Club Memo; he was also a sports enthusiast who helped launch the careers of many in the Negro League in baseball.|~|Bea DeVaughn was someone known for her knowledge of the Los Angeles social scene.|~|Lil Hammond was the ex-wife of Detroit businessman Thomas "Rooster" Hammond. Mrs. Hammond moved to Los Angeles in 1943. She was the proprietor of Lil's Flower Box on west Jefferson.|~|Gwendolyn or Gwen Russell was married to Rev. Clayton D. Russell of the People's Independent Church of Christ, and later the Church of Divine Guidance. She was involved with organizations such as the Independent Guild, which sponsored young men and women financially so they could go to college, and with charity groups such as the 13 Aides Charity Club.|~|Leontyne King was a three-term member of the Los Angeles Public Library Commission, and active in a number of business, governmental and community activities. She and her husband Celes King II were influential members of African American society from the 1940s to the 1970s.|~|Louise Beavers was a well known African American film and television actress. She was a member of the Sigma Gamma Rho sorority and in 1976 was posthumously inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame.|~|Cassie Harris came to Los Angeles from Chicago, and eventually worked at the Dunbar Hotel. She was socially active, and a charter member of the organization 13 Aides, a group of prominent women who devoted their time to organizing programs to support the underprivileged. She was married to Paul Harris, a cook.|~|Hazel Washington was an artist, designer and decorator popular with Hollywood. She was formerly the maid of Hollywood actress Rosalind Russell. The women later became business partners in women's clothing. She also wrote a column for the Chicago Defender titled "This is Hollywood." Mrs. Washingon was married to the policeman Roscoe (Rocky) Washington.|~|Mildred Reed was known for her work with charity organizations such as 13 Aides.

Description.note: LaTanya Griffin is 3rd from the right, and Melba Foppe is at the far right.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon. Walter L. Gordon, Jr. was an African American attorney in Los Angeles.
Summary: LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.|~|Melba Foppe was Walter Gordon's secretary for at least 20 years.

He was also the proprietor of a tavern on Central Avenue that bore his name (it eventually moved to West Adams, near Crenshaw). He died in 1967, at the age of 55.|~|Eddie Jackson was second tenor for The Charioteers, an African American gospel group.

Summary: War Perkins was a radio announcer who also worked as a master of ceremonies. He was a partner in Roy Milton's Miltone label, and ran a pressing plant that pressed the Roy Milton/Miltone series of labels. In addition, he acquired the Mosby & Spikes record shop. Perkins appeared in two movies: Slapsie Maxie's (1939) and Sullivan's Travel (1941, as a churchgoer) (1941). After WWII he sold the record shop, went to the Philippines and set up a pressing plant in Manilla.|~|Herb Jeffries (1913-2014) was a jazz musician and actor.|~|Melba Foppe was a secretary for many years to Walter L. Gordon, Jr.|~|LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Title: Psychologist Howard Emery Wright, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Howard Emery Wright was one of Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s roommates at Ohio State University. Wright was born in Philadelphia in 1908, and attended Lincoln University in Pennsylvania. He later received his M.A. and Ph.D. in psychology from Ohio State, and went on to a long career in higher education, serving as a Dean at Maryland State College and acting Chancellor at the University of Maryland.

Summary: Herman Spurlock, well known on Central Avenue, made a living putting together shows and entertainment for nightclubs and fundraisers.|~|Arthur Houston started out with a small barbershop and pool hall, and later became a licensed real estate broker and contractor. He opened the Crescent Insurance Agency on Central Avenue (across from the Dunbar Hotel) and later a real estate and construction company at a different location. He was also appointed a Real Estate Commissioner for the State of  California later in his career. He was active in the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity, and participated in anti-segregation efforts in Los Angeles and neighboring areas.

Subject.conceptTopic: African American actors|~|African American singers|~|African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American real estate agents $z California $z Los Angeles

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Paul Robeson and C. W. Hill, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Paul Robeson, C. W. Hill.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: C. W. Hill was a Los Angeles real estate agent and businessman.|~|Paul Robeson was an American bass singer and actor who became involved with the Civil Rights Movement. At Rutgers College, he was an outstanding American football player, and then had an international career in singing, with a distinctive, powerful, deep bass voice, as well as acting in theater and movies. He became politically involved in response to the Spanish Civil War, fascism, and social injustices. His advocacy of anti-imperialism, affiliation with communism, and criticism of the United States government caused him to be blacklisted during the McCarthy era. (Wikipedia)

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American actors $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American police $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Scheffield, Maceo B.
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Maceo B. Scheffield and visitors from San Antonio, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Maceo Bruce Scheffield is seated at center, on a stool, holding a glass and a bottle of liquor.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Maceo Bruce Scheffield (1897-1959), (often spelled Sheffield) was an actor who appeared in "race films," made in California. He was also involved in producing and writing films. Before his acting career, he was a high ranking and much-feared policeman in the 1920s and 1930s, known for his intimidating manner while policing other black Angelenos. He was also involved in running nightclubs on Central Avenue.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles
Name.subject: Richardson, H. Leonard, $d 1891-1965|~|Richardson, Maudelle, $d b. 1912
Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: H. Leonard Richardson and his wife Maudelle in a group, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Maudelle and H. Leonard Richardson are seated in the center, 3rd and 4th from the left. The others in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Walter Gordon tidentified the man in the back row, on the left end, as "maybe Malone" [possibly the attorney Stanley Malone].
Summary: Maudelle Richardson was the wife of H. Leonard Richardson. She was an avid golfer.|~|H. Leonard Richardson was born in Cleveland, Ohio in 1891, but his family moved to the Bay Area when he was three. He graduated from UC Berkeley, and after serving as a First Lieutenant in the Army in World War I, he began practicing law in northern California. In 1944, he moved to Los Angeles and married Maudelle Peachey Jones. He was an active NAACP member in both northern and southern California, serving as the head of its Legal Redress committee. He was also active in the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity. He retired from legal practice in 1960, and died in 1965.

Description.note: Walter L. Gordon, Sr. is standing in the second row, 3rd from the right. B. B. Bratton is also in the 2nd row, 6th from the right. C. W. The other individuals in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Horace P. Clark, Sr. was originally from Mississsippi and graduated from Alcorn College. He relocated to Chicago for better job opportunities and became a railroad man. He later moved to Los Angeles where he and his first wife, Vera, built the Clark Hotel.|~|Dr. Frank Gary Zetar was a chiropractor.|~|S.P. Johnson was a director at the Conner-Johnson Mortuary.|~|Afue McDowell was a well-known attorney.|~|Stokes was indentified as a pharmacist assistant.|~|Dr. Charles Wesley Hill moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas. Initially working as a dentist, he became a uccessful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP,  the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) where he was co-vice president along with Lena Horne, and other civil rights organizations. He was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Hill was also a fund raiser and party host at his Hollywood home. According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.|~|B.B. Bratton earned his B.A. from the University of Chicago and worked in Lousiana as a certified public accountant. He passed the bar in Los Angeles in 1924 and practiced law.|~|Mr. Gordon Sr. was Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s father.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: Poets, American $y 20th century|~|Tap dancers $z United States
Name.subject: Johnson, Mae, $d 1916-1999|~|Key, Alyce, $d 1911-2010|~|Nugent, Pete, $d 1909-1973|~|Atkins, Cholly|~|Coles, Honi, $d 1911-1992
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Dancers Charles "Cholly" Atkins, Charles "Honi" Coles, Mae Johnson, Alyce Key, and Gary Lambert "Pete" Nugent, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: At table, left to right: Charles "Cholly" Atkins, Charles "Honi" Coles, Mae Johnson, Alyce Key, and Pete Nugent. Atkins and Coles, preeminent tap dancers, performed together for nineteen years, starting in 1940. Atkins was an expert wing dancer, while Coles's specialty was precision.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Gary Lambert “Pete” Nugent was a preeminent tap dancer in the class act tradition. In the 1930s he was a member of the act of “Pete, Peaches and Duke,” performing in venues such as the Cotton Club. After that he had a solo act “Public Tapper, Number One”.  During World War II he spent his military service touring in Irving Berlin’s show This is the Army. Although Nugent considered himself a tap dancer first and foremost, he preferred “all body motion and no tap”, rather than “all tap and no body motion”. Later, Pete teamed up with Charles “Honi” Coles and opened a dance studio in NYC with called “Dance Craft.” He also performed with Coles in “A History of Tap Dance and its Relationship to Jazz” at the  Newport Jazz Festival, which brought tap back into the public eye.|~|Charles "Honi" Coles was an American actor and tap dancer known for his   extraordinary elegance and technical precision. He learned to dance on the streets of Philadelphia and went on to a  career on stage in vaudeville and the concert world, in film, and on television. He served as president of the Negro Actors Guild and was at the forefront of the tap revival starting in the early 1970s. He brought tap to the world of concert dance with his performance in the Joffrey Ballet production of Agnes De Mille's "Conversations on the Dance", in 1978. In 1983 he received the Tony Award, Fred Astaire Award, and Drama Desk Award for best featured actor and dancer in a musical for the Broadway hit, My One and Only.|~|Alice (Alyce) Key was a Los Angeles dancer who later became a journalist, community activist, and political leader.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.|~|Charles “Cholly” Atkins (1913–2003) was an American dancer and vaudeville performer, who later became noted as the house choreographer for the various artists on the Motown label. (Wikipedia)

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American basketball players|~|African American journalists $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Harding, Halley, $d 1904-1967
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Halley Harding, athlete and sportswriter, at the piano, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: William Claire "Halley" Harding  (sometimes spelled Hally) was a three-sport star in college and the pros who played for both the Kansas City Monarchs and one of the early Globetrotters basketball teams, tried out for the Chicago Cardinals, and appeared with Fritz Pollard’s New York Brown Bombers.  He played baseball in Japan, the Philippines, and Puerto Rico, and somehow managed to stretch out his varsity college football career over (at least) seven seasons and four different schools (Agate Type: Halley Harding, agatetype.typepad.com). He later became a sportswriter for the Los Angeles Tribune. Along with other African American journalists, he led pickets against all-white baseball teams such as the Los Angeles Angels. When the Rams moved to Los Angeles, they applied to lease the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. Harding made a moving speech at the Coliseum Commission's hearing, arguing that since black tax dollars helped build and maintain the Coliseum, none of its tenants should be allowed to discriminate. He also summarized the contributions of black athletes who had played in the NFL before an unwritten color ban was instituted in 1933, and spoke of the sacrifices of African American soldiers in World War II. Rams General Manager  Charles Walsh met with Harding a week after that meeting, at the Last Word, a club on Central Avenue. Harding brought with him influential editors from all three major black weekly papers: the Los Angeles Sentinel, the California Eagle, and the Los Angeles Tribune. Harding's efforts played a key role in the Rams' later decision to sign the black football players Kenny Washington and Woody Strode.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American newspaper editors $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American journalists $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American women political activists $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Bass, Charlotta A., $d 1880-1969|~|Goodrich, Jim, $d 1918-1988
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Charlotta Bass with two associates, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: unidentified man, Charlotta Bass, Jim Goodrich (?).|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Jim (James Russell) Goodrich had a rich and varied journalism career. He obtained a journalism degree from the University of Illinois, and earned two masters degrees from UCLA: in journalism and political science. He was an urban affairs reporter for the Press-Telegram (in Long Beach), and an assistant director of information and reseatch for the Joint Center of Political Studies in Washington D.C.. He was with John son Publications for more than 10 years where he was, at various times, Hollywood editor and associate editor of Ebony magazine and West Coast Bureau chief for Jet magazine. He was the public relationist for Sammy Davis Jr. and, afterwards, as an editor at the Los Angeles Sentinel (1966-67).  He went on to teach at Harbor College, UCLA, and UC  Irvine, then became the director of the Mass Media Program at Central Washington University in Washington state.|~|Charlotta A. Bass was the editor of the California Eagle from 1912 to 1951. The newspaper, which began publishing in 1879, was one of the longest-running African American newspapers in the West. Bass was also a pioneering political activist and erstwhile political candidate.
Description.caption: On back of photograph: Mrs. Bass and some of her later associates. They were not present as yet when I worked for her in 1920-21-22. WLG Jr. May 2004

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American women $z California $z Los Angeles|~|Pottery $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: James, Wilmer, $d 1917-1999
Subject: Lifestyle|~|Arts|~|Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Unidentified African American woman at an art show with ceramic work by Wilmer James, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: This unidentified woman is standing in front of a pedestal with a ceramic statuette, and a table of ceramic objects by the African American potter Wilmer James ceramics. The sign on the table reads: Wilmer James Ceramics.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Wilmer James, one of California’s first African-American designers of commercial ceramics, learned the technique of producing crackle glazes while working for Barbara Willis in North Hollywood. She founded the Ceramics Workshop studio on Jefferson Boulevard (with Tony Hill) in 1944. After the importation of inexpensive European and Japanese ceramics ... rebounded in the late 1950s, many California ceramics manufacturers, including James, went out of business. She went on to become a printmaker, a commercial artist and a prominent arts educator.

Summary: Red (Tom or Tommy) Davis was a well known police officer and athlete on the east side of Los Angeles. Davis was a champion baseball and basketball player at Jefferson, and also played in the Negro leagues during the Depression; later he was the police handball champion 12 times over.|~|Kenneth Harris was a well known police officer and athlete on the east side of Los Angeles. Harris and Red Davis attended Wadsworth Elementary school together, and remained friends; as adults they were partners on the police force for many years.|~|Thomas J. "Tom" Bradley was the 38th Mayor of Los Angeles, serving from 1973 to 1993. He has been the only African-American mayor of Los Angeles, and his 20 years in office mark the longest tenure by any mayor in the city's history.
Description.caption: Inscription: "To Mr. Gordon, Thanks For Everything, The Saints"

Subject.conceptTopic: Real estate business $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Porter, E. J., $d 1886-1965|~|Gordon, Walter L. $q (Walter Lear), $c Sr., $d 1883-1949
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Walter L. Gordon, Sr., and E. J. Porter in Gordon's real estate office, 1920s
Description.note: Walter L. Gordon, Sr., is in the very back of the photo, and E. J. Porter is in the front. The woman and other two men in the photo are unidentified.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr.: "My father took a succession of jobs, each job seemed to be better than the previous one. He first started a shoeshine parlor in Santa Monica, 1906. Then he ended up becoming a mounted postal carrier in Pasadena and also a letter carrier in South Pasadena. But he was a very young man when he started and he was in his 20s. To retire from the Post Office in those days you had to go to a certain age. He was still in his 20s and he'd been with them a gang of years. It was regarded as a good job because he was a mounted carrier, had to take care of his horse and all that. But he then went into the real estate business, and he also started peddling those papers I told you about. Along the way, he finally got himself an office at Adams and Central (Adams and Central would be 26th and Central). There's a lovely shack of a building there, and he moved in there. He's sitting in this old office back there, these in the 20s. And that's my father's original first office. That's him in the back.This man's name is E. J. Porter. E. J. Porter became a pretty well fixed guy, and this is their office originally. And that's the beginning."|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Description.caption: Handwritten note on photo: "My Dad, in rear."

Subject: Lifestyle|~|People

Title: Actor Monte Hawley at a garden party, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Monte Hawley is pictured at left. The woman and the other man in the photograph are unidentified.
Summary: Monte Hawley was one of the most successful African American actors of his time. He got his start in Chicago with the Lafayette Players. From there he moved to New York, where he was a successful stage actor before moving to Hollywood where he found work in motion pictures. Hawley was born in Chicago in 1901, and died in New York City in 1950.

Title: Honey Murphy's Last Chance cafe on Central Avenue, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Honey Murphy is standing, 3rd from the left. To the right of him, in a flowered dress, is Judy Smith.|~|Honey Murphy's Last Chance cafe on Central Avenue at 93rd Street was raided by vice squad officers on December 7, 1947. The cafe was believed that Mr. Murphy was running a brothel within the cafe. Officers used crowbars, sledgehammers and axes to demolish the fixtures and equipment. After the squad reportedly told Murphy he would not be allowed to operate a cafe at the address, he decided to convert the space into apartments.
Summary: Judy Smith was the girlfriend of Sydney Dones' younger brother.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection

Title: Herman Hill, Bud Abbott, Eugene Biscailuz and Mr. Fowler, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R: Bud Abbott (of Abbott and Costello), Mr. Fowler (local man active in politics), Sheriff Biscailuz, and Herman Hill.
Summary: Herman Hill was a newspaper reporter and helped to establish the Pittsburg Courier in Los Angeles.|~|Eugene Biscailuz was a perennial sheriff year after year in Los Angeles county. He was a very popular person. He rode down the street on a beautiful white horse; he raised horses. He had a son, too, who went into politics.|~|Bud Abbott, was an American actor of burlesque, radio, stage, television and film, producer, and comedian. He is best remembered as the straight man of the comedy duo Abbott and Costello, with Lou Costello. (Wikipedia)

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American musicians|~|Lyricists $z United States
Name.subject: Razaf, Andy, $d 1895-1973
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Andy Razaf and his caretaker, Los Angeles, 1950s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Andy Razaf (born Andr Andreamenentania Paul Razafinkeriefo) was born in Washington D.C. to the nephew of Queen Ranavalona III of Imerina (now Madagascar) and the daughter of the first African American consul to that country. He was raised in Harlem, and when he was 17 he wrote his first song. He became a celebrated lyricist, collaborating with composers such as Eubie Blake and Fats Waller. (Perhaps his best-known collaboration with Waller was Ain't Misbehavin'.) He was sometimes called Mr. Tin Pan Alley, as a tribute to the nearly 1500 songs he composed during his career. In the early 1950s, he suffered a spinal injury caused by a fall on ice, and was partially paralyzed. Razaf died in Los Angeles, California, in 1972.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American actors|~|African American boxers
Name.subject: Louis, Joe, $d 1914-1981.|~|Andrade, Muriel, $d 1927-2009|~|Abrams, E. Richard (Edward Richard), $d 1887-1970
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Joe Louis seated at restaurant table with Muriel Andrade, Dick Abrams and others, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.note: Boxer Joe Louis is seated at the restaurant table, 3rd from the left. The woman to his left is Muriel Andrade. Dick Abrams, wearing glasses, is seated on the right. The other individuals in the photo are unidentified.
Summary: "Dick" Richard Abrams was a member of the original Lafayette Players theatrical troup in Harlem, which also  toured during the 1920s and 30s. He appeared in a few motion pictures as well and was dubbed the "sepia Valentino" in the eastern theatrical circles in the mid 1920s. He moved to Los Angeles in the the 1930s and became active in politics and civic work. AFter WWII, he moved to Oxnard where he founded the J. Finley Elks lodge, was its the first president, and also became the  president of the Negro Political Action Association of California for Ventury County.  In the 1960s he sold his ranch properties in Oxnard and moved back to Los Angeles where he resumed local civic activities on a more limited scale.

Seated on couch:  Walter Gordon (wearing glasses, 3rd from L), René (second blond from R, dating Gordon at the time). Gordon, Jr.|~|Cadence Hines was a close friend of Clara Gordon (one of Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s ex-wives).|~|Theodore (Ted) Schaeffer was an attorney who graduated from USC's law school. He later got involved in horserace gambling which, according to Walter Gordon, ruined Mr. Schaeffer financially.|~|Eddie (known professionally as Eadward) Deason was a popular hair stylist who operated "houses of charm" in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Pasadena. Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: Judges $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American clergy $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Russell, Clayton D. (Clayton Donovan), $d 1910-1981|~|Kaufman, Leonard H., $d 1905-1954
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Pastor Clayton D. Russell with Judge Leonard Kaufman, Los Angeles, 1948
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The calendar on the wall is from 1948.
Summary: Rev. Clayton Russell, pastor of the People’s Independent Church, founded in Los Angeles 1915, was a leader of the Double V movement among African Americans during WWII. (Double V stood for victory at home and abroad). Russell’s crusading sermons extended beyond his congregation of 4,000; he had a weekly radio broadcast. In 1940s coalition struggles to achieve fair housing, open hiring in the defense industry, and economic independence, Rev. Russell was in the forefront.

Summary: Frank Ford LaVigne was the youngest captain in the Los Angeles Fire Department, and during World War II he taught classes in fire prevention at Lockheed. He studied law in his spare time, eventually graduating from Southwest School of Law and becoming an attorney. He married Simietta Johnson in 1936, and they had one daughter, Yvette Marie.|~|Simietta Johnson LaVigne was the wife of Frank Ford LaVigne.|~|Tom Bradley was the  mayor of Los Angeles, 1973-1993.

(Sydney Preston), $d 1892-1947|~|Houston, Norman O., $d 1893-1981|~|Broady, Maude Mead, $d 1905-1964|~|Fowler, Jefferson D. $q (Jefferson Davis), $d 1898-1969|~|LaMar, Lawrence F,. $d 1898-1973|~|Bratton, B. B. $q (Bertrand Ballard), $d 1899-1969|~|Nickerson, William, $c Jr., $d 1879-1945|~|Cole, Louis V., $d 1901-1974
Subject: Activism|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Thomas Dewey and Earl Warren campaigning in Los Angeles, circa 1948
Description.note: At the center (in striped tie) is Thomas E. Dewey, campaigning to be President of the United States, with Earl Warren (vice presidential candidate) just to the right of him. Various notable African American activists, businesspersons, and journalists are present: L to R: Louis Cole (1st), Dr. H. A. Pearl (3rd, head half visible), Maude Brody (4th), William Nickerson (6th), B. B. Bratton (7th), Thomas Dewey (8th), Sydney Dones (9th), Earl Warren (10th),  Norman O. Houston (13th, white tie and shirt shows), Lawrence LaMar (17th, at the end). The women in the light-colored dress might be Jessie Terry.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Louis "Louie" V. Cole began his career as a newspaper reporter for the Sentinel and became a civic leader of South Central Los Angeles. He dubbed himself the "Mayor of Central Avenue."|~|Jefferson D. Fowler was a physician and surgeon.|~|Lawrence F. LaMar was a film critic who was published in several newspapers including the Los Angeles Sentinel, the California Eagle and the Los Angeles Times. He had a column titled Through the Keyhole, and he is quoted in several publications on film.|~|William Nickerson, Jr. was the founder of Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company.|~|B.B. Bratton earned his B.A. from the University of Chicago and worked in Lousiana as a certified public accountant. He passed the bar in Los Angeles in 1924 and practiced law.|~|Sidney Dones was a real estate broker and businessman.  He was the first black graduate of LaSalle Extension School, a school that put out legal course materials for people to study at home.|~|Norman Houston was one of the first African Americans to earn a varsity letter in football at UC Berkeley. He graduated from UCLA and became an executive with the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company. He was appointed president of the Los Angeles NAACP in 1964.  He participated in the 1965 Selma, Alabama March. He was Deputy Assistant Secretary for Administration, U. S. Department of Health, Education and Welfare during the Nixon adminisatration 1971-1973.|~|Earl Warren was an American jurist and politician who served as the 30th Governor of California (1943–1953) and later the 14th Chief Justice of the United States (1953–1969). (Wikipedia)|~|Maude Mead Broady was the wife of Judge Earl Broady and lived in the Boyle Heights Neighborhood.|~|Thomas Edmund Dewey was an American lawyer, prosecutor, and politician. He served as the 47th Governor of New York from 1943 to 1954. In 1944, he was the Republican Party's nominee for President. (Wikipedia)

Howard purchase the racehorse Seabiscuit.|~|Fred Williams, a blind man, was a real estate broker and newspaper publisher. Later he became a columnist for the Pittsburgh Courier and a contributer to many other newspapers. He wrote a column titled "Through the Darkness I See."|~|Rich Baker was a business man involved in cafes and other enterprises. He was prominent in political, social and fraternal circles.|~|Walter Lawson was an active politician from Washington, D.C. He moved to Los Angeles and established an office that handled voter registration information.

Mrs. Clark, a former fashion designer, had been married to a police officer Arthur Wilson. She divorced Wilson, and later married Horace P. Clark, Sr., proprietor of the Clark Hotel. After his death, she became the full-time manager of the hotel. Betty was also the sister of Mal (Malvin) Whitfield, Olympic track medalist and member of the Tuskegee Airmen who also spent 47 years in Africa training athletes.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Frederick "Fred" Madison Roberts in Los Angeles, 1930s?
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Frederick Roberts, the first African American elected to the California Assembly, represented a district that was 70% white from 1918–1934 when he was defeated by the New Dealer, a young man named Augustus Hawkins. The Roberts family owned a mortuary in which Frederick was employed; he was also the publisher of the New Age newspaper. The City of Los Angeles named a park after him.

Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Allen C. Woodard, III, attended UCLA and Southwestern Law School in Los Angeles. Once he received his real estate broker's license, he became active in fighting racial restrictions on property ownership and occupation. He also served as President of West View Hospital Organization, supporting the efforts of African American physicians seeking to work at Los Angeles hospitals. He was active in many community organizations, such as the NAACP and YMCA, and also an active member of the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. He died in 1984.|~|Clothilde Woodard was active in Alpha Kappa Alpha (AKA) sorority activities, as well as in the Q-ettes (Wives of Omega Men) organization.

Subject.conceptTopic: African American women $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American women teachers $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American women pharmacists $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American social workers $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American woman librarians $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American actresses $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Matthews, Miriam|~|Honoré, Beulah, $d 1908-1985|~|Beavers, Louise, $d 1902-1962|~|Griffin, Sarah, $d b. 1900 or 01|~|Sissle, Ethel|~|DeVaughn, Beatrice, $d 1901-1989|~|Matthews, Clarissa, $d 1910-1950|~|Johnson, Dorothy Vena, $d 1898-1970|~|Brown, Zepherine|~|Miller, Juanita, $d 1904-1970|~|Portwig, Emily Brown Childress, $d 1896-1960
Subject: Lifestyle
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections|~|Ducket, Leola
Title: Garden party at Loren Miller's house, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Ethel (Sissle) Gordon is sitting on the grass, 1st from the left in the front row. Also in the front row are Sarah Griffin (4th from the left), Dorothy Johnson (5th from the left), Zephrine Brown (9th from the left), and Clarissa Matthews (4th from the right in white dress). Seated in the second row are Bea DeVaughn (3rd from the left) Louise Beavers (4th from the left) and Beulah Honoré (6th from the left). The woman seated to the right of Beulah Honoré with the white hat was identified as Leola Ducket (she is possibly Hazel Anthony). Emily Brown Childress Portwig is standing behind the woman who is seated to the right of Leola Ducket.  Standing in the last row (from far right) are Juanita Miller, Miriam Matthews, and a woman named Vaughn (full name unknown). The woman standing at the end of the second row (far right, carrying purse) is possibly Vera Clark.
Summary: Clarissa Lovinggood Matthews was a teacher in Los Angeles for 15 years. She was the second African American to be assigned to a junior high school position in the district. She was born in San Antonio, Texas in 1910, and was the daughter of Reuben S. Lovinggood, the founder and first president of Sam Huston College. She met attorney Charles H. Matthews in 1930. They married in 1932 and had one son, Charles H., Jr., in 1948.  Mrs. Matthews died in 1950 at age 39 from surgery complications.|~|Miriam Matthews, sister of businesswoman Ella Matthews and lawyer Charles Matthews, was hired in 1927 as the first African American librarian in the Los Angeles Public Library. Matthews was also a civil rights activist, historian, and collector of African American art and primary source materials.|~|Ethel Sissle (1915-1984) was maried to the band leader Noble Sissle, and later to Walter L. Gordon, Jr.|~|DeVaughn was a local activist, known for her knowledge of the Los Angeles social scene.|~|Louise Beavers was a well known African American film and television actress. She was a member of the Sigma Gamma Rho sorority and in 1976 was posthumously inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame.|~|Hazel Anthony was a widow from Chicago.|~|Emily Brown Childress Portwig was well-known for her civic work in Los Angeles and nationally. She attended UCLA and Howard University, and conducted graduate work in bacteriology at USC.|~|Beulah Honoré, a former dancer with the Regalettes in Chicago, and also an interior designer and milliner, was married to Gideon Honoré, a member of Duke Ellington's orchestra.|~|Sarah Griffin was the wife of dentist Tom Griffin.|~|Dorothy Vena Johnson was a poet and educator. With Juanita Miller, a social worker and wife of civil rights attorney Loren Miller, she founded the League of Allied Arts in 1939.|~|Juanita Ellsworth Miller was the wife of Superior Court Justice Loren Miller. The couple had two sons, Loren Jr. and Edward. A graduate of USC's School of Social Work, Mrs. Miller had worked for the State Relief Administration, the Los Angeles Housing Authority, and later the Los Angeles Bureau of Public Assistance. In 1964, she was appointed southern California's social service administrator for the State Department of Social Welfare.
