Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American dentists $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Hudson, H. Claude
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: H. Claude Hudson and an unidentified man, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Dr. Hudson is seated at the left, watching an unidentified man giving a speech.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: H. Claude Hudson had a varied career, working as a dentist, lawyer, and businessman. He was President of the first branch of the National Organization for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) in Shreveport, Louisiana; after he moved his family to Los Angeles, he was elected President of the Los Angeles branch and served in that capacity for 10 years. In 1931, Dr. Hudson became the first African American graduate of Loyola Law School. He never practiced as a lawyer, however. He also founded Broadway Federal Savings and Loan.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American boxers|~|African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Louis, Joe, $d 1914-1981.|~|Matthews, Charles H. $q (Charles Hearde), $d 1906-1985|~|Houston, Norman O., $d 1893-1981|~|Roberts, Frederick Madison, $d 1879–1952
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Norman O. Houston, Joe Louis, Charles Matthews, and Fred Roberts, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Norman O. Houston, Joe Louis, Charles Matthews, Fred Roberts.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Charles Hearde Matthews, Sr. graduated with honors from the Boalt Hall School of Law at UC Berkeley in 1930,  entered the Los Angeles district attorney's office. Matthews was twice denied admission to the Bar Association, at a time when the Association excluded African Americans. (The Bar Association eliminated racial barriers in 1950.) He eventually rose to a key position in charge of the Master Calendar Department of the Superior Court. During this period, Matthews also served as a member of the Los Angeles City Police Commission. He returned to private practice in 1945. Among the many boards and civic organizations on which Matthews served were those of the Los Angeles Metropolitan YMCA, the Los Angeles Chapter of the NAACP, the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance company, and the Liberty Savings and Loan Association.|~|Norman O. Houston helped William Nickerson, Jr. to found the Golden State Mutual Life Insruance Company in1925,  and became president in 1945. At one point, Golden State Mutual Life Insurance was the largest black-owned business west of the Mississippi. He expanded the activities of the company over the next 25 years. In 1970 his two sons, Norman B. Houston and Ivan J. Houston, took over active management of the company. He was also first African American to be appointed to the California State Athletic Commission and later served as chairman.|~|Frederick Roberts, the first African American elected to the California Assembly, represented a district that was 70% white from 1918–1934 when he was defeated by the New Dealer, a young man named Augustus Hawkins. The Roberts family owned a mortuary in which Frederick was employed; he was also the publisher of the New Age newspaper. The City of Los Angeles named a park after him.|~|Joe Louis, known as the Brown Bomber, was the world heavyweight boxing champion from 1937 to 1949.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American police $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Davis, Red, $d b. 14 or 15|~|Harris, Kenneth|~|Davis, Atimus, $d b. 1912 or 13
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: "Red" Davis and Kenneth Harris with wives, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Kenneth Harris (1st from left), Atimus Davis (3rd from left) and Red Davis (right).
Summary: Red (Thomas J., Tom or Tommy) Davis was a well known police officer and athlete on the east side of Los Angeles. Davis was a champion baseball and basketball player at Jefferson, and also played in the Negro leagues during the Depression; later he was the police handball champion 12 times over. Davis and Kenneth (Kenny) Harris attended Wadsworth Elementary school together, and remained friends; as adults they were partners on the police force for many years.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles
Name.subject: Townsend, Vince Monroe, $c Jr., $d 1906-1997|~|Andrade, Muriel, $d 1927-2009|~|Saunders, Joe|~|Lundy, Rayfield, $d 1969-2000
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Vince Monroe Townsend, Joe Saunders, Muriel Andrade, and Rayfield Lundy, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R: Vince Monroe Townsend, Joe Saunders, Muriel Andrade, Rayfield Lundy.
Summary: Joe Saunders was an attorney. Mr. Gordon stated that Joe Saunders was not a Los Angeles attorney.|~|Rayfield Lundy was an attorney.  He was a staunch Republican and became one of their minor officers in the party. He lost his license due to a dispute that involved a client who claimed to have paid Lundy a sum of money, which Lundy denied.|~|Muriel Andrade was born in Martha's Vineyard, and in the 1940s was introduced to and eventually engaged to the heavyweight boxing champion Joe Louis (though she eventually married Ulysses Lear). Her mother was Evelyn DeLoach, secretary to Leverett Saltonstall, governor of Massachusetts from 1939-1945.|~|Vince Monroe Townsend, Jr. was an attorney. Admitted to the California Bar in 1943, he was an advocate for abolishing restrictive covenants for minority groups on real estate in residential areas in the late 1940s. From about 1947 to about 1965, he ran for political office at the city and State levels several times. Affiliated with the Republican Party starting in 1956, he returned to the Democratic Party in 1966.  As of 1966, he was a Los Angeles County public defender. In 1987 he was a judge pro tempore in the Inglewood Municipal Court. Townsend is listed as an actor in three films: Valley of the Head Hunters (1953), Jungle Man-Eaters (1954), and Weird Science (1985).|~|Rayfield Lundy was an attorney. He received his BA degree from Howard University and attended Howard University Law school on a scholarship. He was a staunch Republican and became one of their minor officers in the party. At one point, he lost his license due to a dispute that involved a client who claimed to have paid Lundy a sum of money, which Lundy denied. But he was still a practicing lawyer in the late 1950s. He ran unsuccissfully for the state Legislature, representing the 55th Assembly District. He was very active in Willowbrook civic organizations.

Name.subject: LaVigne, Frank F. (Frank Ford), $d 1911-1973|~|LaVigne, Simietta, $d b. 1912 or 13|~|Johnson, Simuel|~|Houston, Edythe A. $q (Edythe Adelaide), $d 1904-1995

Title: Fire Captain Frank LaVigne with others at a formal gathering, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Frank LaVigne is standing to the far right in a white jacket. The woman beside him is Simietta LaVigne (identified as his 1st wife). The 4th person from the right is Edith Houston. The man to the far left was identified as Simietta LaVigne's father (identified as Simuel Johnson on her marriage certificate). The others in the photo are unknown.
Summary: Frank Ford LaVigne was the youngest captain in the Los Angeles Fire Department, and during World War II he taught classes in fire prevention at Lockheed. He studied law in his spare time, eventually graduating from Southwest School of Law and becoming an attorney. He married Simietta Johnson in 1936, and they had one daughter, Yvette Marie.|~|Edith Houston was the wife of Norman O. Houston, of the Golden State Insurance Company.

Title: Gwendolyn Russell at a children's party, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Gwendolyn or Gwen Russell was married to Rev. Clayton D. Russell of the People's Independent Church of Christ, and later the Church of Divine Guidance. She was involved with organizations such as the Independent Guild, which sponsored young men and women financially so they could go to college, and with charity groups such as the 13 Aides Charity Club. Mrs. Russell as also an elementary school teacher in Los Angeles for 17 years. She passed away in 1965.
Description.caption: Gwendolyn Russell is pictured standing behind a group of seated children.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: Arrivals & departures $x American $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American actors $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American actresses $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Bowman, Laura, $d 1881-1957|~|Davis, Ossie|~|Dee, Ruby
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Laura Bowman, probably with Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Laura Bowman is at the bottom right, standing next to a train. The other two individuals are believed to be actors Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, who married in 1948.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Laura Bowman born in Quincy, Illinois in 1881, and developed an interest in the theater when she was a child. She began her acting career in New York, eventually organizing her own group called the Dark Town Entertainers. They toured the United States and Europe. She later helped to organize the Lafayette Players, who included actors such as Cleo Desmond, Clarence Muse, Abby Mitchell, and others. With her husband, Le Roi Antoine, she moved to Los Angeles in 1940. She continued her acting career, both with the Lafayette Players and independently.|~|Ruby Dee (1922–2014) was an American actress, poet, playwright, screenwriter, journalist and civil rights activist.|~|Ossie Davis (born Raiford Chatman Davis; 1917–2005) was an American film, television and Broadway actor, director, poet, playwright, author, and civil rights activist.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American boxers $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American journalists $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Armstrong, Henry, $d 1912-1988|~|Harding, Halley, $d 1904-1967|~|Jackson, Dynamite, $d 1911-1967|~|Burbridge, Edward Dejoie, $c Sr., $d 1902-1975|~|Robinson, Abie, $d 1915-2001|~|McGee, Paul, $d 1906-1968|~|Shaw, Rainy
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Sportsmen sitting at a table, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|At the head of the table is boxer Dynamite Jackson. Seated on the far left is Rainy Shaw. 3rd from the left is Abie Robinson, and 6th from the left is Henry Armstrong. 1st from the right is Paul McGee, 2nd from the right is Eddie Burbridge, and 3rd from the right is Halley Harding. Mr. Gordon stated that the men at the table either played sports or were sports writers. The others at the table are unknown.
Summary: Rainy Shaw was a liquor store owner.|~|Dynamite Jackson (born Ernest Bendy) won the California state heavyweight title, before going on to become the first African American boxing referee in the state. He was also the proprietor of a tavern on Central Avenue that bore his name (it eventually moved to West Adams, near Crenshaw). He died in 1967, at the age of 55.|~|Eddie Burbridge was a journalist, and served as the Sports Editor for the California Eagle before becoming the Theatrical Editor for the Los Angeles Sentinel. He also wrote poetry.|~|Halley (sometimes spelled Hally) Harding was one of the original members of the Savoy Big Five, a precursor to the Harlem Globetrotters. At one point he was a aide to Walter Gordon, Jr. He later became a sportswriter for the Los Angeles Tribune. Along with other African American journalists, he led pickets against all-white baseball teams such as the Los Angeles Angels. When the Rams moved to Los Angeles, they applied to lease the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. Harding made a moving speech at the Coliseum Commission's hearing, arguing that since black tax dollars helped build and maintain the Coliseum, none of its tenants should be allowed to discriminate. He also summarized the contributions of black athletes who had played in the NFL before an unwritten color ban was instituted in 1933, and spoke of the sacrifices of African American soldiers in World War II. Rams General Manager  Charles Walsh met with Harding a week after that meeting, at the Last Word, a club on Central Avenue. Harding brought with him influential editors from all three major black weekly papers: the Los Angeles Sentinel, the California Eagle, and the Los Angeles Tribune. Harding's efforts played a key role in the Rams' later decision to sign the black football players Kenny Washington and Woody Strode.|~|Edward Joseph "Abie" Robinson was the Los Angeles Sentinel sports editor.|~|Henry Armstrong ("Homicide Hank") was a boxer.|~|Paul McGee was a Los Angeles Sentinel columnist.

He served as the longtime Republican National Committeeman from the U.S. state of Mississippi from 1924 to 1960.|~|Sidney Dones was a real estate broker and businessman.  He was the first black graduate of LaSalle Extension School, a school that put out legal course materials for people to study at home.|~|Jessie Graves was actor and member of Hollywood Screen Actor's Guild. He was known for often playing the role of an austere butler.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American dentists $z California $z Los Angeles|~|Jewish judges $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American real estate agents $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Mosk, Stanley, $d 1912-2001|~|Hudson, H. Claude|~|Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977|~|Jefferson, Edwin, $d 1905-1989|~|Woodard, Allen C., $c III
Subject: Events|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Judge Stanley Mosk addressing an event, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R (at table, facing photographer): two unidentified women, Herman Hill, H. Claude Hudson, Stanley Mosk (standing), Edwin Jefferson, Allen C. Woodard, III, and C. W. Hill. The others in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Allen C. Woodard, III, attended UCLA and Southwestern Law School in Los Angeles. Once he received his real estate broker's license, he became active in fighting racial restrictions on property ownership and occupation. He also served as President of West View Hospital Organization, supporting the efforts of African American physicians seeking to work at Los Angeles hospitals. He was active in many community organizations, such as the NAACP and YMCA, and also an active member of the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. He died in 1984.|~|H. Claude Hudson had a varied career, working as a dentist, lawyer, and businessman. He was President of the first branch of the National Organization for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) in Shreveport, Louisiana; after he moved his family to Los Angeles, he was elected President of the Los Angeles branch and served in that capacity for 10 years. In 1931, Hudson became the first African American graduate of Loyola Law School. He never practiced as a lawyer, however. He also founded Broadway Federal Savings and Loan.|~|Edwin L. Jefferson was the first African American judge west of the Mississippi River, appointed to the Los Angeles Municipal Court (1941), the Los Angeles County Superior Court (1949), and the 2nd District Court of Appeal (1961).|~|Dr. C. W. Hill had a varied, but successful, career as a dentist and real estate broker; he was also involved with the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG), an organization dedicated to protecting the rights of minorities in the entertainment world.|~|In 1947, Mosk issued a ruling declaring restrictive racial covenants to be unconstitutional. He later was elected California's Attorney General (the first Jewish executive branch officer in California) and was appointed to the state Supreme Court in 1964.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American beauty operators $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Davidson, Sadie Louise, $d 1905-1980
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Sadie Louise Davidson with beauty school students, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Sadie Louise Davidson is standing at the far left in front of the microphone. The line of women are her students. The photo was taken at a party.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Sadie Louise Davidson was a hairstylist who founded the Hair Stylist Guild and the Beauticians and Barbers Coordinating Council, and who became the first African American member of the State Board of Cosmetology Advisory Committee. She   produced fasion shows, including The Beauty Salon of Tomorrow at Lincoln Theater (1940). She was also active in many groups, such as the Urban League, the NAACP, the National Council of Negro Women, Indpendent Scholarship Guild of the Independent Church of Christ. She helped found the Alpha Wives Auxiliary adn was  Chairman for Public Relations for the Chi Delta Sorority.
Description.caption: Inscription on photograph: Sadie Louise Davidson "sister of new"|~|Inscription on photograph: Husband "T-Town" Davidson / Alpha man

Name.subject: Miles, Mitchell Bruce, $d 1903-1997|~|Taylor, Brice, $d 1902-1974|~|Houston, Norman O., $d 1893-1981|~|Brooks, Louise Mae, $d 1884-1960|~|Gordon, Walter L., $c Jr., $d 1908-2012|~|Miles, Marshall, $d 1905-1997
Subject: Entertainment|~|Lifestyle
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Picnic party near E. 109th Street and Central Avenue, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Louise Brooks, Walter L. Gordon, Jr., Brice Taylor, an unidentified woman, an unidentified man, Norman O. Houston, Mitchell Miles, Marshall Miles.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Norman O. Houston helped William Nickerson, Jr. to found the Golden State Mutual Life Insruance Company in1925,  and became president in 1945. At one point, Golden State Mutual Life Insurance was the largest black-owned business west of the Mississippi. He expanded the activities of the company over the next 25 years. In 1970 his two sons, Norman B. Houston and Ivan J. Houston, took over active management of the company. He was also first African American to be appointed to the California State Athletic Commission and later served as chairman.|~|Mitchell Miles was a wealthy man from Buffalo, NY. He and his brother ran a gambling business, but they were pushed out of Buffalo by the mob. They eventually moved to Los Angeles.|~|Louise Brooks was in charge of the kitchens at clubs such as the Dunbar Grill and the F-Fortune Club.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr. was an African American attorney in Los Angeles.|~|Brice Union Taylor, who was born without a left hand, was an offensive guard for the USC Trojans football team. He was selected as an All-American in 1925.|~|Marshall Miles was a businessman who helped manage the boxing career of Joe Louis remained his lifelong friend and adviser. Marshall and his brothers, Percy and Mitchell, were among the pioneering African-American businessmen in Buffalo in the 1920's and 1930's, beginning with a shoe-repair shop, then with Miles Brothers Dairy. In addition to managing boxers, Miles branched out into real estate and investments.

Name.subject: Somerville, Vada, $d 1885-1972|~|Hill, Betty, $d 1876-1960|~|Louis, Martha Jefferson, $d 1912-1991|~|Woodie, Emily
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Group of Outstanding Women, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Seated in the front (L to R) are Betty Hill, Dr. Vada Somerville, and Emily Woodie. Back row: 4th from the right is Martha Jefferson Louis. The other women in the photo are unidentified.
Summary: Dr. Vada Somerville was the wife of Dr. John Sommerville. Like her husband, she was a graduate of the USC Dental School (she became the dental school's second black graduate). She and her husband established the Dunbar Hotel in Los Angeles.|~|Emily Woodie was very active in sorority affairs. She was also a school principal.|~|Attorney Martha Jefferson Louis was married a few times. She was first married to a minister named Percy Williams. Her second husband was attorney Bernard Jefferson. She later married boxer Joe Louis. She died in 1991 and is buried at Arlington National Cemetery with Joe Louis.|~|Betty Hill, dubbed by the Los Angeles Sentinel the "Mother of Negro Political Leaders," Hill founded the Women's Republican Study Club (later the Women's Political Study Club) in Los Angeles in 1929. Her many causes included fighting Jim Crow in Los Angeles hospitals and public swimming pools, abolishing separate civil service lists for African American school teachers, and getting the Board of Education to approve a child care center program. Hill was married to Sgt. Abraham Hill.

He moved to Los Angeles and established an office that handled voter registration information.|~|Nelson Creswell was the owner of the Cress Bar in 1947, was known as a fastidious dresser and was frequently mentioned in social reporting in the Los Angeles Sentinel. According to Walter Gordon, Jr., he was known as someone who occasionally sold goods door to door, and who never squealed on anyone as to where they got something.|~|Maudine Simmons Creswell may have been married to Nelson Creswell; she answered to either Maudine Simmons or Maudine Creswell.

Title: Party at photographer George Cutler's house, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Seated on floor (L to R): Lillian Fentress, Chester Washington, Bessie Gant, an unidentified woman, Cullen Fentress. Seated on the couch (L to R): Maudelle Richardson, Gladys Hill, Herman Hill, an unidentified woman, a man identified by his last name "Stubberfield" and an unidentified man. Standing (L to R): an unidentified woman and man, Lois Evans, and George Cutler.|~|Photograph likely taken at the house of a photographer named Cutler; it isn't known if it was Harry Cutler or George Cutler (or neither).|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Chester L. Washington became the first African American news employee at the Los Angeles Mirror-News in 1955, and in 1962 he went to work for The Los Angeles Sentinel, where he became editor. He eventually purchased a number of newspapers, becoming the owner of Central News-Wave Publications. He died in 1983 at the age of 81.|~|Lillian ("Lil") Fentress was active in the Zeta Phi Beta sorority, the YWCA, and in the Los Angeles Elks organization. She was married to J. Cullen Fentress.|~|J. Cullen Fentress was the owner of Fentress Press, and who served as the founding President of the Western States Golf Association. He died in 1989.|~|Maudelle Richardson was the wife of H. Leonard Richardson and an avid golfer.|~|Dr. Lois Evans was a chiropodist.|~|Gladys Hill, married to Herman Hill, was active in civic and social clubs including the Kansis City Brunch Club.|~|Herman Hill was a newspaper reporter and helped to establish the Pittsburg Courier in Los Angeles. He was also the first African American to play varsity basketball at USC.|~|George Cutler was a commercial photographer. In 1942 he lived at 2710 Griffith Avenue.

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Juliette Ball, Lillian Lomax, Mabel Scott and Gertrude Gibson, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: The woman at the far left (seated on the floor in from of man with glasses) is Juliette Ball. To the right and behind her, wearing a dark v-neck top, is Mae Johnson (different from the dancer Mae Johnson). Seated to the far right on the couch are three woman wearing hats: on the left is Lillian Lomax; next to her is Mabel Scott, and at the far right of the couch is Gertrude Gipson. Seated on the floor in the first row is Hazel Moreland (2nd from left) and Lena Torrance (4th from left, wearing a corsage on her dress). The other people in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Mabel Scott was particularly well known for her dramatic hats.|~|Lillian Lomax was the sister of Gertrude Gipson. Lomax later married oral surgeon Dr. Delo Overstreet Gray.|~|Hazel Moreland was the wife of actor Mantan Moreland.|~|Gertrude Gipson Penland was a syndicated columnist, editor, nightclub owner, publicist, and civil rights activist. She was a columnist and entertainment editor for the California Eagle and, then, for the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Juliette Ball was a showgirl and actress.|~|Lena Torance was a socialite and actress.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Actress Mae Johnson on the opening night of Two in a Bed at the Musart Theatre, Los Angeles, 1946
Description.note: Actress Mae Johnson in the middle of a a crowd, behind the Musart Theatre (1320 S. Figueroa) the opening night of the play titled Two in a Bed, which she performed in with Louise Beavers. Mitchell Miles is in the foreground with his back to the camera. Sentinel reporter Wendell Green is standing to the left of Mae Johnson. Millie Monroe is standing at the far right, dressed in a light-colored fur coat. The gentleman standing to the right of Mae Johnson is possibly Bob Bennett.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|This photograph appears with the article by Wendell Green "'Two in a bed' smash hit; set for long run: spicy boudoir farce hilarious laff hit ," Los Angeles Sentinel, 28 Feb.: 1946: 18.
Summary: Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.|~|Millie Monroe Bennett was a showgirl. She was married to Lt. Col. Bob Bennett.|~|Mitchell Miles was a wealthy man from Buffalo, NY. He and his brother ran a gambling business, but they were pushed out of Buffalo by the mob. They eventually moved to Los Angeles.|~|Lt. Col. Bob Bennett was a military man from Detroit. He was married to Millie Monroe.|~|Wendell Green was a Los Angeles journalist, and former managing editor of the Los Angeles Sentinel. During World War II, he reached the rank of Lieutenant in the United States Air Force. He was also a champion of the "Don't buy where you can't work" campaign to boycott businesses that refused to hire African Americans.

Title: Mae Johnson, Nelson Creswell, Rex Ingram, Avanelle Harris, Alyce Key, Count Basie and Charlotte Strickland at the Plantation Club, Los Angeles, 1950s
Description.note: Seated, left to right: Actress and dancer Mae Johnson, Nelson Creswell, Maudine Simmons, unidentified woman, Avanelle Harris, Alyce Key, Charlotte Strickland (light-colored flowers in hair), and Catherine Basie. Standing, left to right: Rex Ingram and Count Basie.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The Plantation Club was located at 108th St. and S. Central Avenue.
Summary: Rex Ingram was an actor.|~|Catherine Morgan was Count Basie's wife.|~|Charlotte (West) Strickland was the wife of Dr. Strickland of Philadelphia (possibly Wilbur H. Strickland?).|~|Nelson Creswell was the owner of the Cress Bar in 1947, was known as a fastidious dresser and was frequently mentioned in social reporting in the Los Angeles Sentinel. According to Walter Gordon, Jr., he was known as someone who occasionally sold goods door to door, and who never squealed on anyone as to where they got something.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.|~|Avanelle Harris at one time was a dancer in the Cotton Club Cuties chorus line. She also performed with the Mosetti Trio act.  She was married to Annanias, of the Berry Brothers.|~|Alice Key was a showgirl who later became a journalist, community activist, and political leader|~|Maudine Simmons Creswell may have been married to Nelson Creswell; she answered to either Maudine Simmons or Maudine Creswell.|~|William "Count" Basie was an American jazz pianist, organist, bandleader and composer.

Title: Lena Horne and actress Mae Johnson on the opening night of Two in a Bed at the Musart Theatre, Los Angeles, 1946
Description.note: Crowd behind the Musart Theatre (1320 S. Figueroa) on the opening night of Two in a Bed, staring Louise Beavers and Mae Johnson. Lena Horne is standing in the center of the photo in a light-colored fur coat. The man standing behind her (facing forward with mustache) is Lee Gaines. To the right of Ms. Horne is actress Mae Johnson (back to the camera). Behind Mae Johnson is Jimmy Mundy (dresed in top hat).  Leonard Reed is standing in the foreground to the far right. The woman in the foreground on the far left was identified as Spurlock (first name unknown).|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|This event was covered in the article,    by Wendell Green "'Two in a bed' smash hit; set for long run: spicy boudoir farce hilarious laff hit ," Los Angeles Sentinel, 28 Feb.: 1946: 18.
Summary: Lena Horne was an American jazz and pop singer, dancer and actress, and civil rights activist.|~|Jimmy Mundy was an arranger, composer, and jazz saxophonist. He worked with popular musicians such as Bennie Goodman, Count Bassie and Earl Hines.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.|~|Leonard Reed started his career as a dancer, became an all-around entertainer. Later he kept a booking office in Hollywood.|~|Lee Gaines was a composer and vocalist, and a founding member of the Delta Rhythm Boys.

Name.subject: Mosk, Stanley, $d 1912-2001|~|Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977|~|Horne, Lena|~|Griffin, Earl|~|Le Berthon, Ted, $d 1892-1960
Subject: Events|~|Media
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) fetes journalists, Los Angeles, Feb. 22, 1946.
Description.note: Photograph taken at Dr. C. W. Hill's house in Hollywood, at an International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) program before an audience of journalists.  The purpose of the IFRG was to protect the rights and interests of minorities in the entertainment world.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R: Stanley Mosk, Earl Griffin, Ted Le Berthon (possibly), Lena Horne (in hat), C.W. Hill (behind Ms. Horne), a man named Silverton (first name unknown), unidentified woman.|~|The man standing 3rd from the left was identified by Mr. Gordon as journalist Ted Le Berthon, but the man's identity is undetermined.
Summary: Lena Horne was an American jazz and pop singer, dancer and actress, and civil rights activist.|~|Publicist Earl "Red" Griffin was the IFRG's public relations director. He was known for discovering and promoting his eventual wife, LaTanya Griffin.|~|Dr. C.W. Hill was co-vice president along with Lena Horne of the International Film and Radio Guild (IRFG). Initially working as a dentist, he became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP,  the IFRG, where he was co-vice president along with Lena Horne, and other civil rights organizations. He was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Hill was also a fund raiser and party host at his Hollywood home. According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.|~|Morey Stanley Mosk was an Associate Justice of the California Supreme Court for 37 years (1964–2001), and holds the record for the longest-serving justice on that court. Before sitting on the Supreme Court, he served as Attorney General of California and as a trial court judge, among other governmental positions.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American clergy $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Russell, Clayton D. (Clayton Donovan), $d 1910-1981
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Pastor Clayton D. Russell with an unidentified man, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Rev. Clayton Russell is standing in the foreground. The other gentleman in the photograph is unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Rev. Clayton Russell, pastor of the People’s Independent Church, founded in Los Angeles 1915, was a leader of the Double V movement among African Americans during WWII. (Double V stood for victory at home and abroad). Russell’s crusading sermons extended beyond his congregation of 4,000; he had a weekly radio broadcast. In 1940s coalition struggles to achieve fair housing, open hiring in the defense industry, and economic independence, Rev. Russell was in the forefront.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: African American media figures, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Left to right: Joe "Smoke Rings" Harris, Walter Winchell, Joe Adams, and Leon Washington, Jr. Photograph most likely taken at one of the Central Avenue nightclubs, such as the Club Alabam.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Leon Washington, Jr. was the founder and publisher of the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Walter Winchell was a newsman and radio commentator.|~|Joe "Smoke Rings" Harris was a Los Angeles reporter and newspaper columnist.|~|Joe Adams was born in Los Angeles in 1924. He overcame racial discrimination to realize his goal of becoming a pioneer radio announcer in the 1940s, on the Santa Monica radio station KOWL. His show soon became the top rated radio show in Los Angeles. In that same decade, he also was known for two television shows, "Adams Alley" on KLAC and "Joe Adams Presents." Adams also appeared in more than 26 motion pictures. In the 1950s, he started working with musician Ray Charles, becoming his manager, producer, and promoter.

The US Supreme Court declared such covenants unconstitutional in 1948.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American dancers $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Johnson, Mae, $d 1916-1999
Subject: People|~|Arts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Dancer and actress Mae Johnson in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.

Subject: Entertainment|~|Events|~|Lifestyle|~|Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Party in a personal residence, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Vince Townsend (likely) is seated on the floor onthe left, David Williams, dressed in a dark suit, is seated on the floor (3rd from the right). Crispus Wright is standing in the back row, 3rd from the right. In front of him (dressed in a light-colored blouse) is Helen Wright.
Summary: Crispus Attucks Wright was a Beverly Hills civil rights attorney, a businessman, and a benefactor to the Law School at the University of Southern California.|~|Helen Wright was the wife of Crispus Attucks Wright and the sister of John McClain.|~|Williams, who in 1969 became the first African American judge appointed to the Federal Court west of the Mississippi, was part of a second generation of lawyers in Los Angeles.|~|Vince Monroe Townsend, Jr. was an attorney. Admitted to the California Bar in 1943, he was an advocate for abolishing restrictive covenants for minority groups in residential areas inthe late 1940s. From about 1947 to about 1965, he ran for political office at the city and State levels several times. Affiliated with the Republican Party starting in 1956, he returned to the Democratic Party in 1966. As of 1966, he was a Los Angeles County public defender. In 1987 he was a judge pro tempore in the Inglewood Municipal Court.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American newspaper editors $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Bass, Charlotta A., $d 1880-1969
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Charlotta Bass, owner and publisher of the California Eagle, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: California Eagle publisher Charlotta Bass, seated at a table in front of a newspaper.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Charlotta A. Bass was the owner and publisher of Los Angeles' oldest black newspaper, the California Eagle, from 1912 to 1951. The newspaper, which began publishing in 1879, was one of the longest-running African American newspapers in the West. Bass was also a pioneering civil rights activist and erstwhile political candidate. She organized the South Los Angeles Protective League, to deal with the ousting of non-white families from all-white neighborhoods; the League went on to become one of the main organizations organizing against restrictive racial covenants in Los Angeles. She walked in picket lines to integrate the aircraft industry, among others.  Bass original came to California from Rhode Island as a very young woman, and married J. B. Bass, then the owner of the California Eagle. She retired in 1959, selling the paper to Judge Loren Miller. She died in 1969.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American football players $z California $z Los Angeles
Subject: People
Name.repository: Strode, Woody|~|University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Woody Strode, Los Angeles, 1930s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Sportsman, actor, Woodrow Wilson "Woody" Strode was born in Los Angeles in 1914. At UCLA, he was part of the renowned trio of student athletes that included LA-area natives Kenny Washington and Jackie Robinson. Following a campaign by the black press, as players for the Los Angeles Rams, Strode and Washington integrated the NFL in 1946. Strode’s film career includes important roles in Spartacus (1960); Sergeant Rutledge (1960); The Professionals (1966), and; Once Upon a Time in the West (1968).

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Name.subject: Val Verde (Calif. : Resort)
Subject: Lifestyle|~|Environment
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Val Verde resort, Santa Clarita Valley, 1940s
Description.note: Prominent African American Angelenos, such as Sydney P. Dones, Norman O. Houston, Joe and Charlotta Bass, and others began constructing a black-owned vacation resort for African Americans in 1924 on 1,000 acres in the Santa Clarita Valley, about 50 miles north of Los Angeles. It was originally called Eureka Villa. The community's slogan was "Industry, Education, Pleasure, Religion." Later, community members changed the name of the community back to Val Verde. In 1940, the resort opened its brand new Olympic-sized pool (pictured here), which was partially financed by the WPA. The resort was tremendously popular, nicknamed "The Black Palm Springs."|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American actors $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Stewart, Nicodemus|~|Griffin, Earl
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Nick (Nicodemus) Stewart with associates, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Nicodemus Stewart was an African American character actor from vaudeville and radio, and later television. He was a cast member on The Amos 'n' Andy Show (playing a character called Lightnin, usually credited as Nick O'Demus), and supplied the voice of Bre'r Bear in the 1946 animated film Song of the South. In 1950, he and his wife Edna founded the Ebony Showcase Theatre in Los Angeles, which was located on Washington Boulevard near La Brea. He was born Horace Winfred Stewart in New York City in 1910, and died in Los Angeles in 2000.|~|The others in the photo with Stewart are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Nicodemus Stewart (upper left), Early Griffin (lower left) with three unideitified people.
Summary: Publicist Earl "Red" Griffin was the IFRG's public relations director. He was known for discovering and promoting his eventual wife, LaTanya Griffin.

Name.subject: McDaniel, Hattie, $d 1895-1952|~|Beavers, Louise, $d 1902-1962|~|Garner, George, $d 1892-1971|~|Garner, Netta Paullyn, $d b. 1906 or 07|~|Peters, Lowell|~|Toney, Jay Stone|~|Odom, Spencer|~|Edmondson, William|~|Southernaires (Musical group)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Louise Beavers, Hattie McDaniel, George and Netta Garner, and the Southernaires, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.note: Seated in the foreground are Spencer Odom (left) and Jay Stone Toney (right). Standing in the center of the photo is Netta Paullyn Garner. To the left is Lowell Peters; to the right is William Edmondson. Standing behind Mrs. Garner on the left is her husband, George Garner. To the left of George Garner is Louise Beavers. Standing in the background (in flower hat) is Hattie McDaniel. The other individuals in the photo are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Pianist Spencer Odom was a member of the gospel group the Southernaires.|~|Jay Stone Toney (baritone) was a member of the gospel group the Southernaires.|~|William Edmondson (bass singer/narrator) was a member of the gospel group the Southernaires.|~|The Southernaires (1930-1950s) was a gospel group that gained radio popularity. The group's original members were Homer Smith (tenor), Lowell Peters (second tenor), Jay Stone Toney (baritone), William Edmondson (bass singer/narrator), and Clarence Jones (pianist). Homer Smith was later replaced by Ray Yeats, and Clarence Jones was replaced by Spencer Odom. The group briefly had a television show, The Southernaires Quartet, on ABC (1948-1949).|~|Lowell Peters (second tenor) was a member of the gospel group the  Southernaires.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American real estate agents $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977
Subject: Transportation|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Successful businessman Dr. C. W. Hill posing with his car, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Based on the hood ornament, the car has been tentatively identified as a 1940s-model Cadillac.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Charles Wesley Hill (commonly known as C.W. Hill) was born in Hartwell, Georgia in 1900, the son of William and Bessie Hill. He moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas, initially working as a dentist. He quickly became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP and other civil rights organizations fighting for full integration for African Americans, as well as a well-known member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Dr. Hill was also a popular figure in African American social circles in Los Angeles, hosting many a party and fundraiser at his Hollywood home (at 5127 Franklin Avenue). According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: Legislators--United States|~|African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American legislators
Name.subject: Hawkins, Augustus F.|~|Alexander, Titus N. (Titus Nathaniel), $d 1870-1952|~|McDonald, Bert A., 1897-1947|~|MacBeth, Hugh, $d d. 1956.
Subject: Transportation|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Augustus Hawkins and Titus Alexander at the Southern Pacific Station, Los Angeles, 1930s
Description.note: Bert McDonald was the first black law school graduate at the University of Southern California (1923) and the first black lawyer in the Los Angeles City Attorney's office, becoming Chief Deputy City Attorney. He was a member of the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity.|~|L to R: unidentified man, Augustus Hawkins, Titus Alexander, unidentified woman, Bert McDonald, Hugh MacBeth.|~|Titus Alexander was a well-known African American civic activist in Los angeles. His father, James M. Alexander, was elected to the Arkansas legislature twice, in 1868 and 1870. A long-time employee in the Bureau of Power and Light, Titus Alexander was also an honorary captain in the Los Angeles Fire Department, who received many civic awards (Los Angeles Fellowship League annual award, the Service Award of the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce, etc.). He died in Los Angeles in 1952.|~|Augustus Freeman Hawkins was elected to the California legislature in 1934, serving until 1963.  From 1963-1991, he represented California in the United States Congress. He was known for his support for civil rights and organized labor. He died in 2007, at the age of 100.|~|Hugh Macbeth came to California in 1913, and practiced law in Los Angeles until his death in 1956. He founded the Los Angeles Lawyers club, and the Society of Truth and Justice and United Races of the World.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.

Lee, who died in 1948.|~|Lillian Tyler was a teacher, was a member of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, and was active in social affairs and civic organizations including the 20-13 Club. She was married to attorney Willis O. Tyler.

Summary: Angelique DeLavallade was the daughter of Louis and Emma DeLavallade of Alexandria, Louisiana. In 1939, she married Bertrand B. Bratton (Los Angeles CPA). Subsequently, she worked for the State of California as a legal stenographer.|~|Miriam Matthews, sister of businesswoman Ella Matthews and lawyer Charles Matthews, was hired in 1927 as the first African American librarian in the Los Angeles Public Library. Matthews was also a civil rights activist, historian, and collector of African American art and primary source materials.

Name.subject: Miller, Loren|~|Vaughn, Betty|~|Vaughn, Ralph|~|Washington, Leon H., $c Jr. $q (Leon Harold), $d 1907-1974|~|Jackson, Dynamite, $d 1911-1967|~|Club Alabam (Los Angeles, Calif.)|~|Washington, Iva, $d 1891-1992|~|Ennis, Charles L. $q (Charles Louvere), $d 1902-1980
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Scene at the Club Alabam, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Front table, left side, front to back: Leon Washington, Loren Miller, and Iva Washington. Front table, right side: Betty (Elizabeth) Vaughn. Two tables down towards the back: Ralph Vaughn (L) and Dynamite Jackson (R) with a woman between them. Standing behind this table is Charles Ennis. The other individuals in the photo are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Elizabeth Estelle Fry Vaughn was the first wife of architect Ralph Vaughn. They had one son, Ronald Vaughn. Elizabeth was a school librarian in Los Angeles for many years. She passed away in Stockton, CA in August 1990 at the age of 78.|~|Ralph Augustine Vaughn was an architect, licensed interior designer and real estate broker. He lived in Los Angeles from 1938-1998. He died in October 2000 in Stockton, CA.|~|Leon Washington, Jr. was the founder and publisher of the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Loren Miller was an attorney at the time; he later became a California Superior Court Justice in Los Angeles County. Miller was known for his work fighting for equal access to housing and education. He was also the editor of the California Eagle after Charlotta Bass.|~|Dynamite Jackson (born Ernest Bendy) won the California state heavyweight title, before going on to become the first African American boxing referee in the state. He was also the proprietor of a tavern on Central Avenue that bore his name (it eventually moved to West Adams, near Crenshaw). He died in 1967, at the age of 55.|~|Charles L. Ennis was a dentist and one of the first African Americans to graduate from the USC School of Dentistry. He was a member of the Kappa Alpha Psi fraternity, a member of the NAACO, and the USC Century Club and supported numerous causes.|~|Iva Washington was one of the first African Americans to teach in the Los Angeles Unified School District. She attended Los Angeles High School and the University of Southern California, where she earned a teaching credential. For most of her career she taught at the 36th Street School in LAUSD.

W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977|~|Carter, Ben, $d 1911-1947|~|Cumber, Lil, $d 1920-2002|~|Green, Norma Ann Amato, $d 1923-2010|~|Randolph, Lillian, $d 1898-1980
Subject: Entertainment
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: African American actors, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Ben Carter, Herman Spurlock (seated), Louise Beavers (seated), Jack Chase, Lillian Randolph Chase, Norma Green, Hattie McDaniel, C. W. Hill, Eddie Green (in profile), George Garner, an unidentified woman, and Lil (Lillian) Cumber.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Ben Carter was an African American character actor on stage, screen, and radio. He often worked as a straight man with Mantan Moreland in vaudeville routines. He acted in many movies, often uncredited, including Maryland (1940) and Reap the Wild Wind (1942). He died in New York in either 1946 or 1947.|~|George Garner was a tenor vocalist and conductor. He was the first African American to sing with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.|~|Lillian Cumber (Victoria Lillian Fisher)  started as a secretary for Walter L. Gordon, was a newspaper columnist for 25 years, and in 1956 founded the Lil Cumber Attraction Agency for African American actors. She was the first African American woman to represent actors in the Motion Picture and Television industry.|~|Herman Spurlock was known for putting together shows and entertainment for nightclubs and fundraisers. He was well known on Central Avenue.|~|Eddie Greenwas an African American  comedian who performed with the Billy Minsky burlesque show for about five years and played the character Eddie the waiter on the radio program Duffy's Tavern.|~|Louise Beavers was a well known African was a member of the Sigma Gamma Rho sorority and in 1976 was posthumously inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame.|~|Lillian Randolph (later Lillian Randolph Chase) was an African American radio, television and film actress, as well as a singer. She was the younger sister of Amanda Randolph (also an actress). Lillian's best known role was the maid Birdie Lee Coggins on the Great Gildersleeve, a radio program that moved to television.|~|Hattie McDaniel was the first African American actress to win an Academy Award, an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress as Mammy in Gone with the Wind.

Bass was the owner and publisher of Los Angeles' oldest black newspaper, the California Eagle, from 1912 to 1951. The newspaper, which began publishing in 1879, was one of the longest-running African American newspapers in the West. Bass was also a pioneering civil rights activist and erstwhile political candidate. She organized the South Los Angeles Protective League, to deal with the ousting of non-white families from all-white neighborhoods; the League went on to become a leader in organizing against restrictive racial covenants in Los Angeles. She walked in picket lines to integrate the aircraft industry, among others. Bass originaly came to California from Rhode Island as a very young woman, and married J. B. Subject: People|~|Media
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Charlotta Bass, editor and owner of the California Eagle, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Charlotta A. Bass was the owner and publisher of Los Angeles' oldest black newspaper, the California Eagle, from 1912 to 1951. The newspaper, which began publishing in 1879, was one of the longest-running African American newspapers in the West. Bass was also a pioneering civil rights activist and erstwhile political candidate. She organized the South Los Angeles Protective League, to deal with the ousting of non-white families from all-white neighborhoods; the League went on to become one of the main organizations organizing against restrictive racial covenants in Los Angeles. She walked in picket lines to integrate the aircraft industry, among others.  Bass original came to California from Rhode Island as a very young woman, and married J. B. Bass, then the owner of the California Eagle. She retired in 1959, selling the paper to Judge Loren Miller. She died in 1969.

Summary: Katherine Garcia was a politically active woman originally from Washington DC, and after she moved to Los Angeles she spent time motivating other women to be active in civic organizations.

Gordon, Jr.: "Alyce Key is compared to Helen Forrest. They both dress alike, they look alike, their features are alike, and they pose alike. It's very hard for most people when they look at the two photographs to not be confused as to which one this is. This apparently is Alyce Key. I get a close-up view here, and the features and facial lines make it more likely this is Alyce Key."

Subject.conceptTopic: African American musicians|~|Musicians--United States|~|African American musicians--California--Los Angeles
Name.subject: Cole, Nat King, $d 1919-1965|~|Cole, Maria, $d 1922-2012|~|Fain, Elmer, $d 1905-1990|~|Hite, Les, $d 1903-1962
Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Elmer Fain, Les Hite, Nat King Cole and Maria Cole, New York City, 1947
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The two women on the left are unidentified. Elmer Fain is third from the left. Third from the right is Les Hite. To his right is Nat King Cole with his future wife, Maria.
Summary: Les Hite was a saxophone musician and bandleader, starting out in New York and relocating to Los Angeles. His big Los Angeles band was called Sebastian's Cotton Club Orchestra. Because he rarely recorded, his work is poorly documented (he recorded some session s bewteen 1940 and 1942). He also ran a talent agency with Elmer Fain.|~|Maria, Nat King Cole's wife, was also known as Maria Hawkins or Maria Hawkins Ellington.|~|Nat King Cole was an American popular singer and jazz pianist.|~|Elmer Fain was a jazz musician and, during the era of segregated bands, the business agent for the the Black Musicians Union. He later became a top talent agent, running an agency with xylophonist and bandleader Les Hite. As the bandleader of Elmer Fain & His Orchestra, he recorded "Bolero at the Savoy," "Pick a Rib," and "Stampede in G Minor" (available in the Big Band Jazz: Junilee Sessions 1943-1946).  He is also credited as an actor in Round-Up Time inTexas (1937), and Hubb's Weekend Trip (1928).

Subject.conceptTopic: African American motion picture actors and actresses--California--Los Angeles|~|African American boxers|~|Motion picture actors and actresses--United States|~|African American insurance executives $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American women political activists $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Menjou, Adolphe, $d 1890-1963|~|Louis, Joe, $d 1914-1981.|~|Beavers, Louise, $d 1902-1962|~|Houston, Norman O., $d 1893-1981|~|Scott, Randolph, $d 1898-1987|~|Hill, Betty, $d 1876-1960|~|Scott, Joseph, $c attorney|~|Graves, Jesse, $d 1879-1949|~|Houston, Doris Talbot Young, 1897-1977
Subject: Activism|~|Entertainment
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Actors and activists in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Joe Louis, Norman O. Houston, Doris Young Houston, Louise Beavers, Adolphe Menjou, Betty Hill, Joseph Scott, unidentified man (possibly actor Jesse Graves, with his back to the camera), Randolph Scott, unidentified man.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Possibly related to war bonds or Double V campaign to beat Hitler abroad and win justice at home.
Summary: Betty Hill was born in Nashville, Tennessee, and moved to Los Angeles in 1912 or 1913. Dubbed by the Los Angeles Sentinel the "Mother of Negro Political Leaders," Hill founded the Women's Republican Study Club (later the Women's Political Study Club) in Los Angeles in 1929. (It eventually expanded throughout the state.) Her many causes included fighting Jim Crow in Los Angeles hospitals and public swimming pools, abolishing separate civil service lists for African American school teachers, and getting the Board of Education to approve a child care center program. Hill was married to Sgt. Abraham Hill, who died in 1948.|~|Doris Young Houston was the wife of Norman O. Houston, co-founder of the Golden State Insurance Company.|~|Adolphe Menjou was a French-American actor.|~|Joseph Scott was an attorney and Catholic layperson.|~|Randolph Scott was an actor.|~|Norman O. Houston helped William Nickerson, Jr. to found the Golden State Mutual Life Insruance Company in1925,  and became president in 1945. At one point, Golden State Mutual Life Insurance was the largest black-owned business west of the Mississippi. He expanded the activities of the company over the next 25 years. In 1970 his two sons, Norman B. Houston and Ivan J. Houston, took over active management of the company. He was also first African American to be appointed to the California State Athletic Commission and later served as chairman.|~|Louis, known as the Brown Bomber, was the world heavyweight boxing champion from 1937 to 1949.|~|Louise Beavers was a well known African American film and television actress. She was a member of the Sigma Gamma Rho sorority and in 1976 was posthumously inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame.

Louise Beavers is at center in front, holding a bouquet of flowers. Leonard Reed is to the right of Beavers. Directly behind Beavers is Lee Gaines (with moustache). Jimmy Mundy, facing away, is wearing a top hat of the right.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|This event is covered in the article, by Wendell Green "'Two in a bed' smash hit; set for long run: spicy boudoir farce hilarious laff hit ," Los Angeles Sentinel, 28 Feb.: 1946: 18.
Summary: Otho Lee Gaines was born in Houston, Texas in 1914. He was a composer and vocalist, and a founding member of the Delta Rhythm Boys. He died in Helsinki, Finland in 1987.|~|Louise Beavers was a well known African American film and television actress. She was a member of the Sigma Gamma Rho sorority and in 1976 was posthumously inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame.|~|Leonard Reed started his career as a dancer, became an all-around entertainer. Later he kept a booking office in Hollywood.|~|Jimmy Mundy was an arranger, composer, and jazz saxophonist. He worked with popular musicians such as Bennie Goodman, Count Bassie and Earl Hines.

Name.subject: McDaniel, Hattie, $d 1895-1952|~|Chase, Jack, $d 1917-1972|~|Beavers, Louise, $d 1902-1962|~|Spurlock, Herman|~|Garner, George, $d 1892-1971|~|Green, Eddie, $d 1901-1950|~|Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977|~|Carter, Ben, $d 1911-1947|~|Cumber, Lil, $d 1920-2002|~|Green, Norma Ann Amato, $d 1923-2010|~|Randolph, Lillian, $d 1898-1980
Subject: Entertainment
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: African American actors, Los Angeles, 1940s (2nd photo)
Description.note: Mr. Gordon identified the woman on the far left as Mrs. Jennie Bruington, but the woman's identity is undetermined.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Standing (L to R): unidentified woman, Ben Carter, Jack Chase, Lillian Randolph, Hattie McDaniel, C.W. Hill, George Garner, unidentified woman, Lil Cumber. Seated in the front (L to R): Herman Spurlock, Louise Beavers, Norma Green, Eddie Green.
Summary: Hattie McDaniel was the first African American actress to win an Academy Award, an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress as Mammy in Gone with the Wind.|~|Lillian Cumber (Victoria Lillian Fisher)  started as a secretary for Walter L. Gordon, was a newspaper columnist for 25 years, and in 1956 founded the Lil Cumber Attraction Agency for African American actors. She was the first African American woman to represent actors in the Motion Picture and Television industry.|~|Herman Spurlock, well known on Central Avenue, made a living putting together shows and entertainment for nightclubs and fundraisers.|~|Louise Beavers was a well known African American film and television actress. She was a member of the Sigma Gamma Rho sorority and in 1976 was posthumously inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame.|~|Norma Green was the wife of actor Eddie Green. Mrs. Green was a singer, and she played the piano and violin. The couple had a daughter, Elva Diane.|~|Eddie Green played the character Eddie the waiter on the radio program Duffy's Tavern.|~|Jack Chase was married to actress Lillian Randolph Chase.|~|Ben Carter was an African American character actor on stage, screen, and radio. He often worked as a straight man with Mantan Moreland in vaudeville routines. He acted in many movies, often uncredited, including Maryland (1940) and Reap the Wild Wind (1942). He died in New York in either 1946 or 1947.|~|Lillian Randolph (later Lillian Randolph Chase) was an African American radio, television and film actress, as well as a singer. She was the younger sister of Amanda Randolph (who went on to become an actress). In the 1940s, she and her husband, boxer Jack Chase, purchased a home in the "Sugar Hill" district (West Adams), but could not move in because of restrictive racial covenants. The US Supreme Court declared such covenants unconstitutional in 1948.|~|Dr. Charles Wesley Hill moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas. Initially working as a dentist, he became a uccessful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP,  the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) where he was co-vice president along with Lena Horne, and other civil rights organizations. He was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Hill was also a fund raiser and party host at his Hollywood home. According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.|~|George Garner was a tenor vocalist (and first African American to sing with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra) and conductor.

He headed a public relations firm with boxer Joe Louis, and was the first African-American deputy Police Commissioner in New York. He was also known as an aviator, a fabulous dancer, and was very popular in social circles.|~|Hazel Moreland was the wife of actor Mantan Moreland.

Next to her is Elihu "Black Dot" McGee (looking forward). Seated across from Lillian Randolph at the same table is Juliette Ball (smiling). To the far right of the photo, seated at the front of the stage, is Prince Spencer (head resting on hand). To the far left of the photo is Tillie Euliss (seated in the front, dressed in hat and long fur coat). Across from her at the same table is Lil "Hammie" Hammond (smiling).|~|The Club Alabam was located at 4015 S. Central Ave.
Summary: Clarence Moore was the proprietor of the Last Round and Club Memo on Central Avenue. He also started a semi-professional baseball team called the Clarence Moore's All-Stars in 1934 as a means to launch baseball careers for local youths.|~|Elihu "Black Dot" McGee was a night club owner and sportsman. He owned establishments around Central Avenue, including the Turf Record Shop, the Sportsman's Club, The Casa blanca and The Downbeat (co-owned).|~|Lillian Randolph (later Lillian Randolph Chase) was an African American radio, television and film actress, as well as a singer. She was the younger sister of Amanda Randolph (who went on to become an actress). In the 1940s, she and her husband, boxer Jack Chase, purchased a home in the "Sugar Hill" district (West Adams), but could not move in because of restrictive racial covenants. The US Supreme Court declared such covenants unconstitutional in 1948.|~|Juliette Ball was a showgirl and actress.|~|Prince Spencer was an African American tap dancer, who was born in 1917 in South Carolina. In 1941, he joined the dance troupe the Four Step Brothers.|~|Tillie Euliss was a socialite known for her hats.|~|Lil Hammond was the ex-wife of Detroit businessman Thomas "Rooster" Hammond. Mrs. Hammond moved to Los Angeles in 1943. She was the proprietor of Lil's Flower Box on west Jefferson.

Title: Constance Baker Motley (?) and her sister, 1940s
Description.note: Location of photo is unknown.|~|The woman on the right has been tentatively identified as Constance Baker Motley.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Constance Baker Motley was the first African American woman to serve in the New York state Senate, and the first woman to be a Manhattan borough president. During the 1940s, she held a position with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund in New York, where she worked for 20 years. In this capacity, she became one of the first women to argue cases before the Supreme Court (winning 9 out of the 10 cases she argued). In 1966, she was appointed as a judge on the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York by President Lyndon B. Johnson.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Melvyn Douglas, Ouida Williams, L'Tanya, David Williams and others at a political event, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Melvyn Douglas is at the far left. Third from the left is Ouida Williams. David W. Williams is at the far right. Third from the right is LaTanya Griffin.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: David W. Williams, who in 1969 became the first African American judge appointed to the Federal Court west of the Mississippi, was part of a second generation of lawyers in Los Angeles.|~|Melvyn Douglas was an actor and husband of actress and politician Helen Gahagen Douglas.|~|Ouida Williams was the wife of attorney David W. Williams.|~|LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino. She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.|~|George Cannady started out as a firefighter, at a time when African American firefighters were rare. Later he went into the real estate business, and later still he became a lawyer. Name.subject: Ice Water
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Ice Water, musician and narcotics peddler, Los Angeles, 1943
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Walter L. Gordon, Jr: “Ice Water”was a narcotics peddler, and the Feds got him. The case was in San Francisco. I had to drive him up to San Francisco. We had a jury trial. They convicted him fair and squarely. He comes out of prison, and he goes back to his hometown [Los Angeles]. He's grateful, and he sends me a photograph. He was running a gas station. “Outrageous.” He was mad at the judge.
Description.caption: On front of photograph: [unintelligible] my hat off befo[re] a Lady. The fact is my hands are full. [unintelligible] the world. Sonny. Oswald.|~|On back of photograph: To counsellor Walter Gordon. From Ice Water. Outrageous. 1943. Los Angeles, Central Ave., Trivoli Studios.

Name.subject: Sissle, Ethel|~|Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Businessman C. W. Hill and Ethel (Sissle) Gordon, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: an unidentified white couple, Ethel (Sissle) Gordon, and C. W. Hill.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Ethel Sissle (1915-1984) was maried to the band leader Noble Sissle, and later to Walter L. Gordon, Jr.|~|Charles Wesley Hill (commonly known as C.W. Hill) was born in Hartwell, Georgia in 1900, the son of William and Bessie Hill. He moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas, initially working as a dentist. He quickly became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP and other civil rights organizations fighting for full integration for African Americans, as well as a well-known member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Dr. Hill was also a popular figure in African American social circles in Los Angeles, hosting many a party and fundraiser at his Hollywood home (at 5127 Franklin Avenue). According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.

Summary: Nelson Creswell was the owner of the Cress Bar in 1947, was known as a fastidious dresser and was frequently mentioned in social reporting in the Los Angeles Sentinel. According to Walter Gordon, Jr., he was known as someone who occasionally sold goods door to door, and who never squealed on anyone as to where they got something.|~|Maudine went by the last names Simmons and Creswell at different times.

Lomax later married oral surgeon Dr. Delo Overstreet Gray.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.

Name.subject: Griffin, L'Tanya, $d 1919-1996
Subject: Lifestyle|~|Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: L'Tanya and another swimsuit model, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: On the left is LaTanya Griffin. The woman on the right is unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino. She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Group of men from Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Back row: Herbert Simmons (far left); next to him is a man identified as Parks (first name unknown). Also in back row: Don Barksdale (4th from left), Dewey "T. Town" Davidson (1st from right), and Joe Oliver (3rd from right). The others in the photograph are unidentified.
Summary: Don (Donald Angelo) Barksdale was a basketball player. While at UCLA, he became the first African American named All-American in 1947. He was also the first African American to play on the U.S. Olympic basketball team, in the 1948 Summer Olympics. He later went on to play basketball in the NBA, with the Baltimore Bullets and Boston Celtics.|~|Dewey Daniel Davidson was a prominent African American businessman in Los Angeles, proprietor of the largest mercantile store west of Chicago. He was also very active in the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity, serving for some years as the regional director. He was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma, which lead some to call him by the nickname "T-Town." He was the husband of Sadie Louise Davidson.|~|Herbert Simmons, Jr., was an attorney, admitted to the bar in 1949. He was Chairman of the Los Angeles NAACP and promoted civil rights his law practice, such as enforcement of anti-segregation in seating on public transport. He was a member of the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity.|~|Joe Oliver played basketball at Hollywood High School in 1938-1939 and was active in the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity in the 1940s, as reported in the Los Angeles Sentinel.

Summary: Louise "Bo" Franklin was a chorus girl, dancer and actress who appeared in nightclubs and movies from the 1930s to the 1950s.Louise danced in legendary films, "Cabin In The Sky" and "Stormy Weather," and appeared in many Lena Horne's musicals. She was also a featured dancer in Duke Ellington's Jump For Joy and many other stage shows, and she a star of a stage version of the musical Sweet and Hot.
