Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American journalists|~|African American newspaper editors $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Harding, Halley, $d 1904-1967|~|Height, Dorothy I. $q (Dorothy Irene), $d 1912-2010|~|Hill, Herman, $d 1906-1991|~|Gant, Bess M., $d 1896-1962|~|Washington, Leon H., $c Jr. $q (Leon Harold), $d 1907-1974|~|LaMar, Lawrence F,. $d 1898-1973|~|Burbridge, Edward Dejoie, $c Sr., $d 1902-1975|~|Hardwick, Leon|~|Cole, Louis V., $d 1901-1974|~|McGee, Paul, $d 1906-1968
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Newspaper gathering, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Standing at the far left is Halley Harding. Also standing (R to L) are Eddie Burbridge, Lawrence LaMar, Louie Cole, a man identified as one of the Irving Brothers (publishers of the Neighborhood News), and Leon Washington. Seated (R to L) are Paul McGee, Leon Hardwick, and Dorothy Height (Mr. Gordon identified the woman as Dorothy Height, but she might be journalist Bessie Gant). The man seat 4th from the left is Herman Hill. The others in the photograph are unidentified.
Summary: Lawrence F. LaMar was a film critic who was published in several newspapers including the Los Angeles Sentinel, the California Eagle and the Los Angeles Times. He had a column titled Through the Keyhole, and he is quoted in several publications on film.|~|Herman Hill was a journalist and also the first African American to play varsity basketball at USC.|~|Halley (sometimes spelled Hally) Harding was one of the original members of the Savoy Big Five, a precursor to the Harlem Globetrotters. At one point he was a aide to Walter Gordon, Jr. He later became a sportswriter for the Los Angeles Tribune. Along with other African American journalists, he led pickets against all-white baseball teams such as the Los Angeles Angels. When the Rams moved to Los Angeles, they applied to lease the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. Harding made a moving speech at the Coliseum Commission's hearing, arguing that since black tax dollars helped build and maintain the Coliseum, none of its tenants should be allowed to discriminate. He also summarized the contributions of black athletes who had played in the NFL before an unwritten color ban was instituted in 1933, and spoke of the sacrifices of African American soldiers in World War II. Rams General Manager Charles Walsh met with Harding a week after that meeting, at the Last Word, a club on Central Avenue. Harding brought with him influential editors from all three major black weekly papers: the Los Angeles Sentinel, the California Eagle, and the Los Angeles Tribune. Harding's efforts played a key role in the Rams' later decision to sign the black football players Kenny Washington and Woody Strode.|~|Bessie M. Gant was a columnist from the Pittsburgh Courier.|~|Leon Washington, Jr. was the founder and publisher of the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Louis "Louie" V. Cole began his career as a newspaper reporter for the Sentinel and became a civic leader of South Central Los Angeles. He dubbed himself the "Mayor of Central Avenue."|~|Eddie Burbridge was a journalist, and served as the Sports Editor for the California Eagle before becoming the Theatrical Editor for the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Paul McGee was a Los Angeles Sentinel columnist.|~|Leon Hardwick started his career at the newspaper The Call and went on to work as a public relations expert.

Name.subject: Honoré, Beulah, $d 1908-1985|~|Fowler, Laura Bruce, $d 1905-2006|~|Griffin, Sarah, $d b. 1900 or 01|~|McPherson, Marjorie Eloise, $d 1906-1958|~|Stovall, Yolande|~|René, Margaret Carter, $d 1905-1986|~|Fowler, Jefferson D. $q (Jefferson Davis), $d 1898-1969|~|René, Otis, $d 1898-1970|~|Green, Norma Ann Amato, $d 1923-2010|~|Griffin, Thomas, $d 1902-1959|~|Stovall, Leonard S.|~|Portwig, Emily Brown Childress, $d 1896-1960
Subject: Lifestyle
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Formal event attended by physicians and others at a hall, Los Angeles 1940s
Description.abstract: Emily Brown Childress Portwig was well-known for her civic work in Los Angeles and nationally. She attended UCLA and Howard University, and conducted graduate work in bacteriology at USC.
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Seated on the floor, from the left: Otis René (1st), Ursula (Pruitt) Murrell (2nd), Sarah Griffin (3rd) and Norma Green (4th), an unidentified woman (5th),  Margaret René (6th) Marjorie McPherson (7th), Beulah Honoré (8th), unidentified woman and Margaret Carter René (on the far R). Second row: Mrs. Taylor (1st from L), Laura Fowler (2nd from L), Dr. Frank Robinson (5th from L), Dr. Clifford Gordon (5th from right), and Emily Portwig (4th from right). Third row: Dr. Watkins (far R).Forth row: Dr. Leonard Stovall (1st from L, looking towards the left), Yolande Stovall (2nd from L, wearkin a 2-strand pearl choker), Tom Griffin (center), standing in front of a woman (woman is in last row, 9th from the right). Back row: Dr. Bauman (4th from L), Dr. Jefferson D. Fowler  (4th from R), Dr. Taylor (1st on R). The other individuals in the photo are unidentified.
Summary: Margaret Carter René was married to the composer Otis René.|~|Dr. Frank Robinson was a medical doctor on Central Avenue.|~|Dr. Clifford Gordon was a physician and surgeon. He was originally from Fargo, North Dakota. He went to USC for pre-medical training and eventually attended Howard University's School of Medicine. He died in 1952 at the age of 51.|~|Marjorie Bright McPherson was married to Dr. Henry McPherson. She was a school administrator.|~|Sarah Griffin was the wife of dentist Tom Griffin.|~|Tom Griffin was a dentist.|~|Otis René was the brother of Leon René, and with him and Clarence Muse composed the song "When It's Sleepy Time Down South" (Louis Armstrong's theme song). The song was composed at the Baumann-René drugstore on 14th and Central, where Otis was a pharmacist.|~|Norma Green was the wife of actor Eddie Green. Mrs. Green was a singer, and she played the piano and violin. The couple had a daughter, Elva Diane.|~|Emily Brown Portwig was a Los Angeles pharmacist.|~|Laura Fowler was the wife of physician Jefferson D. Fowler.|~|Yolande Stovall was the wife of Dr. Leonard Stovall.|~|Beulah Honoré, a former dancer with the Regalettes in Chicago, and also an interior designer and milliner, was married to Gideon Honoré, a member of Duke Ellington's orchestra.|~|Jefferson D. Fowler was a medical doctor.|~|Dr. Leonard Stovall (1887-1956) was the first African American doctor to be appointed to the staff of Los Angeles County General Hospital.

Title: Ben Carter and Henry Armstrong on stage, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Actor Ben Carter is standing at the far left. Boxer Henry Armstrong is standing at the microphone. The other individuals in the photo are unidentified.
Summary: Ben Carter was an African American character actor on stage, screen, and radio. He often worked as a straight man with Mantan Moreland in vaudeville routines. He acted in many movies, often uncredited, including Maryland (1940) and Reap the Wild Wind (1942). He died in New York in either 1946 or 1947.|~|Henry Armstrong ("Homicide Hank") was a boxer.

Name.subject: Griffin, L'Tanya, $d 1919-1996
Subject: People|~|Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: L'Tanya models a white satin dress, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: Showgirls $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Boyd, Mildred, $d 1909-
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Mildred Boyd, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Mildred Boyd was an actress and dancer. She was born in 1909 in Tennessee, but moved to Los Angeles in her late teens or early 20s. She began her entertainment career in the 1920s and  became a chorus girl at popular black nightclubs in Los Angeles. She later appeared in movies in which she often portrayed the role of the maid. Later in her career she was able to play different roles and showcase her acting and dancing talents in race films. She retired from entertainment in the 1950s.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American real estate agents $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American women singers
Name.subject: Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977|~|Brown, Anne, $d 1912-2009
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Anne Wiggins Brown and C. W. Hill in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Charles Wesley Hill (commonly known as C.W. Hill) was born in Hartwell, Georgia in 1900, the son of William and Bessie Hill. He moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas, initially working as a dentist. He quickly became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP and other civil rights organizations fighting for full integration for African Americans, as well as a well-known member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Dr. Hill was also a popular figure in African American social circles in Los Angeles, hosting many a party and fundraiser at his Hollywood home (at 5127 Franklin Avenue). According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.|~|Anne Wiggins Brown was an African American soprano radio and concert singer, perhaps best known for singing the part of Bess in the world premier of Porgy and Bess in Boston. In the late 1940s, Brown moved to Norway, to escape the continuing racial prejudice in the United States.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American newspaper editors $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American journalists $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Bass, Charlotta A., $d 1880-1969|~|Beavers, Jessie Mae Brown, $d 1923-1989|~|Goodrich, Jim, $d 1918-1988|~|Burbridge, Edward Dejoie, $c Sr., $d 1902-1975|~|Gibson-Penland, Gertrude, $d 1923-1999|~|Hardwick, Leon
Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections|~|Gray, Lillian Lomax, $d 1924-1984
Title: Charlotta Bass and others, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Seated at the head of the table is Charlotta A. Bass. Seated on the far side of the table, from the L: Lillian Lomax  (1st), Gertrude Gipson (2nd), and Jessie Mae Brown Beavers (5th). Standing, from the L: Leon Hardwick (1st), Jim Goodrich (?) (3rd), and Eddie Burbidge (4th).
Summary: Charlotta A. Bass was the editor of the California Eagle.|~|Jessie Mae Brown Beavers was a journalist and editor for the Los Angeles Sentinel. She was also a community activist. She was married to insurance executive LeRoy A. Beavers, Jr. (he passed away in 2010 at age 87). They had three children together. Mrs. Brown Beavers died in 1989.|~|Leon Hardwick started his career at the newspaper The Call and went on to work as a public relations expert.|~|Lillian Lomax was the sister of Gertrude Gipson. Lomax later married oral surgeon Dr. Delo Overstreet Gray.|~|Gertrude Gipson Penland was a syndicated columnist, editor, nightclub owner, publicist, and civil rights activist. She was a columnist and entertainment editor for the California Eagle and, then, for the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Eddie Burbridge was a journalist, and served as the Sports Editor for the California Eagle before becoming the Theatrical Editor for the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|Jim (James Russell) Goodrich had a rich and varied journalism career. He obtained a journalism degree from the University of Illinois, and earned two masters degrees from UCLA: in journalism and political science. He was an urban affairs reporter for the Press-Telegram (in Long Beach), and an assistant director of information and reseatch for the Joint Center of Political Studies in Washington D.C.. He was with John son Publications for more than 10 years where he was, at various times, Hollywood editor and associate editor of Ebony magazine and West Coast Bureau chief for Jet magazine. He was the public relationist for Sammy Davis Jr. and, afterwards, as an editor at the Los Angeles Sentinel (1966-67).  He went on to teach at Harbor College, UCLA, and UC  Irvine, then became the director of the Mass Media Program at Central Washington University in Washington state.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Yvonne Shelton and Katherine Alexander, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R: Yvonne Shelton with older sister Katherine Alexander.
Summary: Katherine "Kat" Alexander (née Catherine Porter) started out as a secretary for Walter L. Gordon, Jr. She and sister Yvonne Shelton became bail bonds agents. Together they ran the Shelton Bail Bonds Co., and were the first black women licensed to do so in California. Katherine was also an avid bowler. She passed away in 2000 at age 80.|~|Yvonne, with sister Katherine Alexander, was a bail bonds agent who ran the Shelton Bail Bonds Co. She and her sister were the first black women to become licensed agents in the state of California.

Murrell (2nd from L), Sarah Griffin (4th from L), Mrs. Tyler (8th from L), Edythe A. Houston (7th from R), Olive Neal (6th from R), Zepherine Brown (5th from R), Nancy Cunningham (2nd from R)
Summary: Sarah Griffin was the wife of dentist Tom Griffin.|~|Edythe Houston was the wife of Norman O. Houston, of the Golden State Insurance Company.|~|Ursula P. Murrell was a pharmacist for 14 years. She then received a bachelor's degree and a master's degree at the University of Southern California. She also did post-graduate work at U.C. Berkeley and UCLA. She was a special music teacher in the Los Angeles Unified School District for 30 years. She was awarded the Honorary PTA Life Membership, the Life Membership in the Los Angeles City Elementary School Music Association 24th Street Elementary School Award, and the Golden Apple at the 1971 Teacher Remembrance Day Award as Outstanding Teacher.  She was also very active in civic organizations. Her mother, Loretta H. Dunn Pruitt, was the frost African American woman to graduate from college degree in Louisiana.|~|Olive Neal was the wife of the dentist Elvin Neal.|~|Edythe Houston was the wife of Norman Houston, of the Golden State Insurance Company.

Title: Singers Norma Green, Anne Brown & George Garner with pianist Netta Garner and C. W. Hill, Los Angeles, 1940s

Summary: Dr. Charles Wesley Hill moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas. Initially working as a dentist, he became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP,  the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) where he was co-vice president along with Lena Horne, and other civil rights organizations. He was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Hill was also a fund raiser and party host at his Hollywood home. According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.|~|George Garner was a tenor vocalist (and first African American to sing with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra) and conductor.|~|Anne Wiggins Brown was an African American soprano radio and concert singer, perhaps best known for singing the part of Bess in the world premier of Porgy and Bess in Boston. In the late 1940s, Brown moved to Norway, to escape the continuing racial prejudice in the United States.|~|Norma Green was the wife of actor Eddie Green. Mrs. Green was a singer, and she played the piano and violin. The couple had a daughter, Elva Diane.|~|Netta Paullyn (aka Pauline) Garner was a concert pianist, married to George Garner.

Subject: Entertainment|~|Lifestyle|~|Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Well-dressed group dining out, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Seated on left side of table, L to R: Mabel Miles (1st), Edythe Houston (2nd). Seated of right side of table, L to R: Norman O. Houston (1st), Mitchel Miles (2nd). Standing at the far end of the talbe: Floyd Snelson. Standing in the back: Eddie Atkinson (4th from L).
Summary: Eddie Atkinson (J. Edward) was a market developer for the Carnation company. He was the first African American to run for Los Angeles City Council, losing by only 1,000.|~|Mitchell Miles was a wealthy man from Buffalo, NY. He and his brother ran a gambling business, but they were pushed out of Buffalo by the mob. They eventually moved to Los Angeles.|~|Norman O. Houston helped William Nickerson, Jr. to found the Golden State Mutual Life Insruance Company in1925,  and became president in 1945. At one point, Golden State Mutual Life Insurance was the largest black-owned business west of the Mississippi. He expanded the activities of the company over the next 25 years. In 1970 his two sons, Norman B. Houston and Ivan J. Houston, took over active management of the company. He was also first African American to be appointed to the California State Athletic Commission and later served as chairman.|~|Floyd Snelson was a newspaper man.

Title: At home with friends, Los Angeles, 1950s
Description.note: L to R, on couch: Kenneth Levy, Honore Levy, Newell Eason, Scottie (Hines) Eason, Dr. Arthur Mitchell and his wife Gloria. L to R, on floor: Clara Gordon, an unidentified girl, Cadence Hines, Walter Hines.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Newell Eason was the husband of Scottie Hines Eason, and a good friend of Walter Gordon. He was a vice principal of a school. He was also a member of the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity.|~|Dr. Walter Hines was a surgeon. He was the husband of Cadence Hines.|~|Gloria Mitchell was the wife of Dr. Arthur Mitchell.|~|Scottie Hines Eason, a school principal, was the sister of Dr. Walter Hines.|~|Dr. Arthur Mitchell was a physician and an acquintance of Walter Gordon and Clara Gordon.|~|Clara Gordon was one of Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s ex-wives. She was married to Harold Young before marrying Walter Gordon.|~|Kenneth Levy was the husband of Honore Levy.|~|Cadence Hines was a close friend of Clara Gordon (one of Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s ex-wives).|~|Honore Levy was employed in local high schools, eventually working her way up to the position of head student counselor at Jefferson High School. She was active in organizations such as the Delta Sigma Theta sorority, the Allied Arts League, and the Sojourner Truth Home (her mother was a founding member).

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Floyd C. Covington, executive director of the Los Angeles Urban League, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: In the 1930s, Floyd C. Covington was a social worker, and later became the executive director of the Los Angeles branch of the National Urban League from 1931-1950; later he was the racial relations advisor with the Federal Housing Administration from 1950-1975. He was known as an important civic leader in Los Angeles, a "go to" guy.

Name.subject: Robinson, Louis George, $d 1876-|~|Griffin, Thomas, $d 1902-1959|~|Gray, Mabel V. $q (Mabel Vernon), $d 1895-1981|~|Terry, Jessie L., $d 1885-1973
Subject: Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: African American civic leaders, Los Angeles, 1930s
Description.note: Jessie Terry is 4th from the left, Dr. Tom Griffin is 5th from the left, L. G. Robinson is at the center hugging a woman wearing a white scarf, Mabel Gray is at the far right.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Mabel Gray was an active member of Los Angeles' early African American society. She was involved in various charity organizations, such as the Five-and-Over Charity Club, as well as the PTA. She served as President of the Los Angeles Federation of Women's Clubs, representing the city and national meetings.|~|Jessie L. Terry was a civic leader in Los Angeles. Among her achievements, in 1917 she and others founded the first African American branch of the YWCA, and she was the first African American to be appointed to the Housing Authority board.|~|Jessie Terry was a prominent civic leader.|~|Tom Griffin was a dentist.|~|Louis (sometimes spelled Lewis) George Robinson, more commonly known as L. G. Robinson, was an important early African American civic leader in Los Angeles. Originally from Barnesville Georgia, he moved to Los Angeles in 1904. Initially, he worked for the county, rising through the ranks until he became the supervisor of all county janitors and elevator operators (a workforce of approximately 350). Later he founded and was the President of the Angelus Funeral Home on Jefferson. Robinson was active in organizations as varied as the 28th Street YMCA, the NAACP, the Urban League, the Masons, and the Ancient Order of Foresters. He was also an elder in the C.M.E. (Christian Methodist Episcopal) church, often honored with the title of Reverend. He died in 1959.

Subject: Arts
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Dancers and musicians, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Red Mack (Morris), unidentified man, Mae Johnson, unidentified man, Nicodemus Stewart (white shirt), Frances Turnham, unidentified man, Luke Jones (with saxophone), unidentified man.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Frances Turnham Robinson, along with her husband Earl Robinson, was a dancer. She was the daughter of entertainer Edith Turnham and the sister of musician Floyd Turnham.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.|~|Nick Stewart (1910–2000) was an American television and film actor. Stewart was known for his role as Lightnin' (Willie Jefferson)[1] on TV's The Amos 'n' Andy Show. (Wikipedia)|~|Red Mack (Morris McClure) was an American jazz trumpeter and vocalist. Mack was raised in Los Angeles and was a pianist for his local Church of God in Christ as a youth.  (Wikipedia)

Subject: Entertainment|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Peters Sisters publicity photograph by James Kreigsman, inscribed to Ethel Sissle, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The members of the vocal trio The Peters Sisters (Mattye, Anne and Virginia).|~|The Peters Sisters (Mattye, Anne and Virginia) were natives of Santa Monica, California who performed primarily in Europe.
Summary: Anne Peters Katz was a member of The Peters Sisters, a vocal trio from Santa Monica, California that performed primarily in Europe. She died in Paris.|~|Virginia Peters Engel was a member of The Peters Sisters, a vocal trio from Santa Monica, California that performed primarily in Europe. She died in Paris.|~|Mattye (Mattie) Peters Wolgaard was a member of The Peters Sisters, a vocal trio from Santa Monica, California that performed primarily in Europe. The 11/2/1978 issue of Jet magazine reported the she was vacationing in the US, her husband was Herman Wolgaard and she was living in Copenhagen. She died in Copenhagen (date unknown).|~|James J. Kriegsmann (1909–1994) Immigrated to New York from Vienna at the age of 20. There he became a celebrity and theatrical photographer, working from 1929 to the early 1960s. In addition to his work as a photographer to the stars, Kriegsmann wrote hundreds of songs for top recording artists of the day. He ran his studio with his two sons, James J. Kriegsman, Jr. and Thomas O. Kriegsmann. Kriegsmann became the official in-house photographer for Harlem’s Cotton Club, and he was considered among the best photographers in America.
Description.caption: Handwritten on photograph: "To Ethel" [refers to Ether Sissle]|~|Photographer signature on photograph: James Kriegsman & Co.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American basketball players
Name.subject: Barksdale, Don, $d 1923-1993
Subject: Sports|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Basketball player Don Barksdale, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Don Barksdale (left) is receiving a trophy.
Summary: Don (Donald Angelo) Barksdale was a basketball player. While at UCLA, he became the first African American named All-American in 1947. He was also the first African American to play on the U.S. Olympic basketball team, in the 1948 Summer Olympics. He later went on to play basketball in the NBA, with the Baltimore Bullets and Boston Celtics.

She was married to Paul Harris, a cook.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American singers
Name.subject: Terrell, Pha, $d 1910-1945
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Singer Pha Terrell and an unidentified woman, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Elmer "Pha" Terrell standing with an unidentified woman in a fur coat.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr.: "Pha Terrell. That's the one I told you about the other day that could sing so well. 'Until the Real Thing Comes Along,' that was his song. It used to close down places to hear Pha Terrell. His name became so synonymous with beauty that most people would turn their things off so they could hear him sing it. I saw them explode on the scene, because he struggled to get going. She was a white girl, and she was poor. He was hustling, and he was poor. And they're trying to get a spot, trying to get a hit, and they were both loyal to one another. Then they ended up, they got a little taste, and a guy gave them a spot on one show. But when this thing came along, it exploded over the whole country. Money just poured into them. 'Until the Real Thing Comes Along.' Last thing I knew... I don't remember their demise, but they were a fine little couple. [Do you remember her name?] No, she was a nonentity. You just knew she was loyal to him. You almost pitied them because they struggled so hard to get going, and to see them reaping success... You were just proud they were able to make it. I'm so glad you got that one." From an interview on August 3, 2010.

Summary: Sam Taylor was a chauffeur (for Duke Ellington, among others), "sportsman," and proprietor of the club Sam's Place.|~|LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American boxers|~|Nightclubs $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American journalists $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Louis, Joe, $d 1914-1981.|~|Goodrich, Jim, $d 1918-1988
Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Boxer Joe Louis, Jim Goodrich (?), and an unidentified woman at a nightclub in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Champion Joe Louis is in the center, with Jim Goodrich (?) to the left and an unidentified woman at the right.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Jim (James Russell) Goodrich had a rich and varied journalism career. He obtained a journalism degree from the University of Illinois, and earned two masters degrees from UCLA: in journalism and political science. He was an urban affairs reporter for the Press-Telegram (in Long Beach), and an assistant director of information and reseatch for the Joint Center of Political Studies in Washington D.C.. He was with John son Publications for more than 10 years where he was, at various times, Hollywood editor and associate editor of Ebony magazine and West Coast Bureau chief for Jet magazine. He was the public relationist for Sammy Davis Jr. and, afterwards, as an editor at the Los Angeles Sentinel (1966-67).  He went on to teach at Harbor College, UCLA, and UC  Irvine, then became the director of the Mass Media Program at Central Washington University in Washington state.|~|Joe Louis was a heavyweight boxing champion.

Title: Herb Jeffries performing in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Jazz musician and actor Herb Jeffries stands at a microphone. The other musicians in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Herb Jeffries was the first African American actor to star in American western films, such as "Harlem on the Prairie"; he was known as the "Bronze Buckaroo." "Race movies" such as these were among the first to depict African Americans as something other than subservient characters such as servants. He retired from acting in 1939, and went on to sing and tour with Duke Ellington's orchestra.
Description.caption: The name "Elihu McGee" is written on the back of the photograph, but appears to have nothing to do with the image.

She was formerly the maid of Hollywood actress Rosalind Russell. The women later became business partners in women's clothing. She also wrote a column for the Chicago Defender titled "This is Hollywood." Mrs. Washingon was married to the policeman Roscoe (Rocky) Washington.

The women in this photograph are unidentified, most likely waitresses in local clubs. The woman on the far left, wearing the "Sam Taylor" sash, is possibly the sister of boxer Joe Louis.|~|The woman on the left is identified as "(Barrow) Joe's Lewis sister". Two sisters of Jow Lewis are identified as Eulala Barrow and Bunis Barrow (a mistake; she was named Vunies; later Vunis High) in the 1930 Census.
Summary: Lionel Leo Hampton was an American jazz vibraphonist, pianist, percussionist, bandleader and actor.|~|Sam Taylor was a chauffeur (for Duke Ellington, among others), "sportsman," and proprietor of the club Sam's Place.|~|Nelson Creswell was the owner of the Cress Bar in 1947, was known as a fastidious dresser and was frequently mentioned in social reporting in the Los Angeles Sentinel. According to Walter Gordon, Jr., he was known as someone who occasionally sold goods door to door, and who never squealed on anyone as to where they got something.

Name.subject: Griffin, L'Tanya, $d 1919-1996|~|Jeffries, Herb
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: War Perkins, L'Tanya, and Herb Jeffries in a group, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Forrest "War" Perkins is standing in the back, 7th from the left. LaTanya Griffin is in the center, wearing a dark outfit with a floral spray on her shoulder. Herb Jeffries is holding Griffin's left arm. The other people in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: War Perkins was a radio announcer who also worked as a master of ceremonies. He was a partner in Roy Milton's Miltone label, and ran a pressing plant that pressed the Roy Milton/Miltone series of labels. In addition, he acquired the Mosby & Spikes record shop. Perkins appeared in two movies: Slapsie Maxie's (1939) and Sullivan's Travel (1941, as a churchgoer) (1941). After WWII he sold the record shop, went to the Philippines and set up a pressing plant in Manilla.|~|Herb Jeffries was a movie star, whose character was known as the "Bronze Buckaroo."|~|LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Second row: Arthur Houston (2nd from L), Herman Spurlock (3rd from L).
Summary: Arthur Houston started out with a small barbershop and pool hall, and later became a licensed real estate broker and contractor. He opened the Crescent Insurance Agency on Central Avenue (across from the Dunbar Hotel) and later a real estate and construction company at a different location. He was also appointed a Real Estate Commissioner for the State of  California later in his career. He was active in the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity, and participated in anti-segregation efforts in Los Angeles and neighboring areas.|~|Herman Spurlock, well known on Central Avenue, made a living putting together shows and entertainment for nightclubs and fundraisers.

Name.subject: Ali, Bardu, $d 1906-1981|~|De los Santos, Otila, $d 1909-1997
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Bardu Ali and Tila de los Santos, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|The woman and man seated in the center are Tila de los Santos and her boyfriend (later husband) Ali Bardu. The other two people in the photograph are unidentified.
Summary: Bardu Ali was an American jazz and rhythm-and-blues singer, guitarist, and promoter. From 1921 to 1929 he performed in a precision dance team with his brother Abdeen, called the Ali Brothers. Afterwards, he became master of ceremonies for the bands of Leroy Tibbs, Chick Webb, and Napoleon Zyas. He is credited with persuading Webb to hire Ella Fitzgerald. After 1943 he moved to Los Angeles. He produced shows and was a band leader at the Lincoln Theatre, and, in 1946, produced comedy skits and talent shows at tFollies Burlesk Theatre. From 1948-51 he  performed in Johnny Otis's band and opened the Barrelhouse Club with him, and was Otis' road manager from 1951-63. He is credited with introducing Etta James to Johnny Otis. He played an important role in the early career of Charles Brown and was Redd Foxx's business manager.|~|Otila (usually referred to as "Tila"), originally from San Antonio, operated a restaurant near the Club Alabam.

Name.subject: Harding, Halley, $d 1904-1967|~|Washington, Leon H., $c Jr. $q (Leon Harold), $d 1907-1974|~|Fentress, J. Cullen, $d 1910-1989|~|Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Leon Washington, Jr. and others, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Leon Washington is in the center of the group, standing, wearing a bow tie. C. W. Hill is behind him, to his left. Halley Harding is 2nd from the right, and J. Cullen Fentress is at the far right. The others in the photo are unidentified.
Summary: Leon Washington, Jr. was the founder and publisher of the Los Angeles Sentinel.|~|J. Cullen Fentress was the owner of Fentress Press, and  served as the founding President of the Western States Golf Association. He died in 1989.|~|Dr. Charles Wesley Hill moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas. Initially working as a dentist, he became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP,  the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) where he was co-vice president along with Lena Horne, and other civil rights organizations. He was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Hill was also a fund raiser and party host at his Hollywood home. According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.|~|Halley (sometimes spelled Hally or Hallie) Harding was Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s aide and a former Harlem Globetrotter.

Name.subject: Miller, Loren|~|Maddox, Albert, $d 1903-1995|~|Nickerson, William, $c Jr., $d 1879-1945|~|Johnson, Edgar J., $d 1904-2001|~|Cannady, George E., $d 1913-1968|~|Herndon, Bernard C. $q (Bernard Christopher), $d 1902-1959 |~|Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977|~|Howard, H. A. $q (H. Alexander), $d 1900-1972
Subject: Lifestyle|~|Business|~|Legal
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: African American business and legal figures, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Standing: Bernard Herndon (3rd from left), Al Maddox (5th from right), George Cannady (4th from right), H. A. Howard (3rd from right), Loren Miller (2nd from right), and Edgar Johnson (far right). Seated at far right: William Nickerson. Seated at lower left: C. W. Hill.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: George Cannady started out as a firefighter, at a time when African American firefighters were rare. Later he went into the real estate business, and later still he became a lawyer. He died in 1968.|~|H. A. Howard was a business entrepreneur who founded and was the president of the Broadway Federal Savings and Loan Association. He was very active in civic organizations and was a vice president of the local chapter of the NAACP.|~|Edgar J. Johnson rose from agent to president of the Golden State Mutual Insurance Company.|~|Bernard C. Herndon who moved to Los Angeles around 1940. He was a real estate broker and president of the non-profit Stovall Foundation for community health and welfare.|~|William Nickerson Jr. was a prominent Los Angeles-based businessman and founder of Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, which at one time was the largest black-owned business west of the Mississippi.|~|Dr. Charles Wesley Hill moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas. Initially working as a dentist, he became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP, the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) where he was co-vice president along with Lena Horne, and other civil rights organizations. He was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Hill was also a fund raiser and party host at his Hollywood home. According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.|~|Loren Miller (1903-1967) was an attorney in the 1940s. he later became a California Superior Court Justice in Los Angeles County. Miller was known for his work fighting for equal access to housing and education. He was also the editor of the California Eagle after Charlotta Bass.|~|(C.) Albert (Al) Maddox founded the Maddox Realty Company, the Maddox Construction Company, was a co-founded  Broadway Federal Savings and Loan Association, and the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Golden West Real Estate Board. He also participated in numerous civic organizations and was a lifetime member of the NAACP.

Name.subject: Scheffield, Maceo B.|~|Ray, Arthur, $d 1888-1942.|~|Woods, Buck|~|Clisby, Jack|~|Thompson, Edward, $c actor
Subject: Entertainment|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Maceo Scheffield, Arthur Ray, and other actors in a still from a movie, Los Angeles, late 1930s or early 1940s
Description.note: L to R: unidentified actor, Jack Clisby (aka Clissby), Eddie Thompson, Ira "Buck" Woods, Maceo Sheffield, and Arthur Ray.|~|Still is possibly from the movie Double Deal, which played at the Lincoln Theater in Los Angeles.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Los Angeles actor Maceo Bruce Scheffield (sometimes spelled Sheffield) appeared in, wrote, and/or produced many so-called race movies (films with African American casts made specifically for African American audiences) in the 1930s and 1940s. He often played menacing or intimidating characters or villains. Scheffield was a member of the Screen Actors guild, who organized to pressure movie theaters to show films made by and with African Americans. Before he became an actor, he was a police detective; he also managed nightclubs on Central Avenue.

Title: Lena Horne and C. W. Hill, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: unidentified woman, Lena Horne, and C. W. Hill.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Lena Horne was an American jazz and pop singer, dancer and actress, and civil rights activist.|~|Dr. Charles Wesley Hill moved to Los Angeles from Arkansas. Initially working as a dentist, he became a successful businessman and real estate broker. Hill was active in the NAACP,  the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG) where he was co-vice president along with Lena Horne, and other civil rights organizations. He was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity. Hill was also a fund raiser and party host at his Hollywood home. According to Walter L. Gordon, Jr., at some point Mr. Hill simply disappeared from the Los Angeles scene, and no one knew what had become of him. Census records indicate that he died in Evansville, Indiana in 1977.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American women journalists $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Bass, Charlotta A., $d 1880-1969|~|Beavers, Jessie Mae Brown, $d 1923-1989|~|Darby, Al|~|Burbridge, Edward Dejoie, $c Sr., $d 1902-1975
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Journalists Charlotta Bass, Jessie Mae Brown Beavers, and others, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Jessie Mae (Brown) Beavers was a pioneering black journalist, who began her career at the California Eagle, moving to the Los Angeles Sentinel in 1948. She was a Los Angeles native, who graduated from Los Angeles High School and studied sociology at UCLA. She was a life member of the NAACP, and helped to organize local chapters of the National Association of Media Women and the Black Women's Forum. She also served for 16 years on the Los Angeles Human Relations Commission. She was married to Leroy Albert Beavers Sr.

Title: Formal affair in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Standing, from L: Lillian Tyler (2nd, dress with lace sleeves), Eddie Atkinson, Sr. (3rd), Norman O. Houston (5th), Mrs. Damon Lee (6th, white dress and glasses), H. Leonard Richardson (11th, just R of chandelier). Standing , from R: Luther M. Hudson (7th), Dr. W. E. Bailey (4th), Wesley Fairchild ( 2nd). Seated, from L: "Jay" Fairchild (1st, in print dress), Vada Somerville (2nd), Edith Banks (Pruett?) (6th).
Summary: Lillian Tyler was a teacher, was a member of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, and was active in social affairs and civic organizations including the 20-13 Club. She was married to attorney Willis O. Tyler.|~|Mrs. Damon Lee was the assistant to the Somervilles of the Somerville Hotel (later the Dunbar Hotel).|~|"Jay" Fairchild was the wife of Wesley J. Fairchild, who operated the Fairchild Realty Co. after running a laundry.|~|Wesley J. Fairchild operated the Fairchild Realty Co. after running a laundry.|~|Luther M. Hudson was a funeral director and one of the original founders of the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company.|~|Norman O. Houston helped William Nickerson, Jr. to found the Golden State Mutual Life Insruance Company in1925,  and became president in 1945. At one point, Golden State Mutual Life Insurance was the largest black-owned business west of the Mississippi. He expanded the activities of the company over the next 25 years. In 1970 his two sons, Norman B. Houston and Ivan J. Houston, took over active management of the company. He was also first African American to be appointed to the California State Athletic Commission and later served as chairman.

Name.subject: Wilson, Arthur D. $q (Arthur Darafoniere), $d 1896-1954|~|Clark, Betty Whitfield Wilson, $d 1912 or 13-1998

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Arthur Wilson and Betty Clark, with others, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Arthur Wilson is standing to the far left. Betty Clark is standing in the center, dressed in a hat and fur. The others in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Betty Clark (née Betty Whitfield Wilson), was the wife of Horace Clark. Mrs. Clark, a former fashion designer, had been married to a police officer Arthur Wilson. She divorced Wilson, and later married Horace P. Clark, Sr., proprietor of the Clark Hotel. After his death, she became the full-time manager of the hotel. Betty was also the sister of Mal (Malvin) Whitfield, Olympic track medalist and member of the Tuskegee Airmen who also spent 47 years in Africa training athletes.|~|Arthur Wilson was a police officer.

Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Kenneth Harris was a well known police officer and athlete on the east side of Los Angeles. Harris and Red Davis attended Wadsworth Elementary school together, and remained friends; as adults they were partners on the police force for many years.|~|Red (Tom or Tommy) Davis was a well known police officer and athlete on the east side of Los Angeles. Davis was a champion baseball and basketball player at Jefferson, and also played in the Negro leagues during the Depression; later he was the police handball champion 12 times over. Davis and Kenneth (Kenny) Harris attended Wadsworth Elementary school together, and remained friends; as adults they were partners on the police force for many years.//Police officer Tommy "Red" Davis was white, but known to get along with African Americans.

Summary: Jerome Johnson was a physician.|~|LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Branham was the pastor at St. Paul Baptist church.|~|Loren Miller was an attorney at the time; he later became a California Superior Court Justice in Los Angeles County. He was also the editor of the California Eagle after Charlotta Bass.|~|Marshall Shepherd was the U.S. Recorder of Deeds in Washington, D. C. and pastor of Philadelphia's Mount Olivet Baptist church.|~|W. D. Carter was a minister at the Friendship Baptist Church in Pasadena.|~|Jonathan L. Caston was pastor at Trinity Baptist Church; he ran to represent District 7 on the Los Angeles City Council (he narrowly lost to Don Allen).

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American women teachers $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American poets
Name.subject: Miller, Loren|~|Vena Johnson, Dorothy|~|Pruitt Murrell, Ursula|~|Tolbert, Mary Lou|~|Griffin, Sarah, $d b. 1900 or 01|~|Garrott, Helen, $d 1896-1966
Subject: Entertainment|~|Lifestyle
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Backyard party in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Dorothy Vena Johnson is fourth from the left, with her back to the photographer. Loren Miller is visible in the center of a group on the left side of the photograph. Mary Lou (Roberson) Tolbert is at the far left of the group on the right side of the photograph. Sarah Griffin is in the same group, near the back wall of the house. Helen (Duncan) Garrott is fourth from the right, in a group of women closer to the photograph. Ursula (Pruitt) Murrell is at the far right of the photograph. The others in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Dorothy Vena Johnson was a poet and educator.|~|Loren Miller was an attorney. He later became a California Superior Court Justice in Los Angeles County. Miller was known for his work fighting for equal access to housing and education. He was also the editor of the California Eagle after Charlotta Bass.|~|Sarah Griffin was the wife of dentist Tom Griffin.|~|Dorothy Vena Johnson was a poet and educator. With Juanita Miller, a social worker and wife of civil rights attorney Loren Miller, she founded the League of Allied Arts in 1939.|~|Ursula P. Murrell was a pharmacist for 14 years. She then received a bachelor's degree and a master's degree at the University of Southern California. She also did post-graduate work at U.C. Berkeley and UCLA. She was a special music teacher in the Los Angeles Unified School District for 30 years. She was awarded the Honorary PTA Life Membership, the Life Membership in the Los Angeles City Elementary School Music Association 24th Street Elementary School Award, and the Golden Apple at the 1971 Teacher Remembrance Day Award as Outstanding Teacher.  She was also very active in civic organizations.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Name.subject: Hill, Herman, $d 1906-1991|~|Gant, Bess M., $d 1896-1962|~|Fentress, J. Cullen, $d 1910-1989|~|Richardson, Maudelle, $d b. 1912|~|Washington, Chester L.|~|Fentress, Lillian|~|Hill, Gladys, $d b. 1907 or 08|~|Cutler, George M. (George Miles), $d 1901-1949|~|Evans, Lois J., 1913-1986
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Party at photographer's house, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Seated on floor (L to R): Lillian Fentress, Chester Washington, Bessie Gant, an unidentified woman, Cullen Fentress. Seated on the couch (L to R): Maudelle Richardson, Gladys Hill, Herman Hill, an unidentified woman, a man identified by his last name "Stubblefield" and an unidentified man. Standing (L to R): an unidentified woman and man, Lois Evans, and George Cutler.
Summary: Chester L. Washington became the first African American news employee at the Los Angeles Mirror-News in 1955, and in 1962 he went to work for The Los Angeles Sentinel, where he became editor. He eventually purchased a number of newspapers, becoming the owner of Central News-Wave Publications.|~|Gladys Hill, married to Herman Hill, was active in civic and social clubs including the Kansis City Brunch Club.|~|Herman Hill was a newspaper reporter and helped to establish the Pittsburg Courier in Los Angeles. He was also the first African American to play varsity basketball at USC.|~|J. Cullen Fentress was the owner of Fentress Press, and served as the founding President of the Western States Golf Association.|~|Lillian ("Lil") Fentress was active in the Zeta Phi Beta sorority, the YWCA, and in the Los Angeles Elks organization. She was married to J. Cullen Fentress|~|Dr. Lois Evans was a chiropodist.|~|Maudelle Richardson was the wife of H. Leonard Richardson and an avid golfer.|~|George Cutler was a commercial photographer.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American singers $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Miles, Mitchell Bruce, $d 1903-1997|~|Miles, Mabel|~|Sissle, Ethel|~|Garner, George, $d 1892-1971|~|Garner, Netta Paullyn, $d b. 1906 or 07|~|Hill, C. W. $q (Charles Wesley), $c Dr., $d 1900-1977|~|Green, Norma Ann Amato, $d 1923-2010|~|Brown, Anne, $d 1912-2009|~|Woodard, Clothilde Curry, $d 1907-2001|~|Murrell, Ursula P. (Pruitt), $d 1905-1995|~|Hill, Tony, $d 1904 or 05-1975|~|Griffith, Portia, $d 1905-1989|~|Towles, Ruth Lee
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Soprano Anne Brown, tenor George Garner, pianist Netta Garner, and others, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Guests at a gathering. Seated on the floor, L to R: (Portia Griffith (?) (2nd), Norma Green (3rd), Clothilde Woodard (4th), Mabel Miles (7th), Ruth Le Towles (8th). Second row (L to R): Anne Brown (3rd), Netta Garner (6th). Standing: Tony Hill (far L), Ursula Murrell (9th from R, below wall sconce, hat work at angle), Ethel Sissle (8th from R, dark hat), Mitchell Miles (7th from R), C. W. Hill (4th from R), George Garner (far R).
Summary: Tony Hill was the owner of the Tony Hill Ceramics Workshop, located at 3121 W. Jefferson Blvd. for 31 years. He received his AB in Social Work from the University of Chicago; did graduate work in sociology at Columbia University, New York School of Social Work; and was the first African American to study art and ceramics with Glen Lukens at the University of Southern California. He died of a heart attack, and was buried, in Cairo, Egypt during a trip to the far east.|~|Mabel Miles was the wife of Mitchell Miles.|~|Portia Griffith taught at Tuskegee Institute and worked for the Los Angeles Unified School District for 26 years. She was a founding member of USC’s Upsilon Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta sorority, and of the Dilettante Bridge Club, the A.D.D. Club, Belle Lettres, and Friendly Educators. She was married to attorney Tom Griffith.|~|Norma Green was the wife of actor Eddie Green. Mrs. Green was a singer, and she played the piano and violin. The couple had a daughter, Elva Diane.|~|Ethel Sissle (1915-1984) was maried to the band leader Noble Sissle, and later to Walter L. Gordon, Jr.|~|Clothilde Woodard was active in Alpha Kappa Alpha (AKA) sorority activities, as well as in the Q-ettes (Wives of Omega Men) organization.|~|Ruth Lee Towles was a milliner from Chicago, who may have settled in Los Angeles around 1950. She was a stylist for Marva Louis and other fashionable women. Society columns note that she was also a pianist who played at social events.|~|George Garner was a tenor vocalist (and first African American to sing with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra) and conductor.|~|Dr. C. W. Hill had a varied, but successful, career as a dentist and real estate broker; he was also involved with the International Film and Radio Guild (IFRG), an organization dedicated to protecting the rights of minorities in the entertainment world|~|Netta Paullyn (aka Pauline) Garner was a concert pianist, married to George Garner.|~|Ursula P. Murrell was a pharmacist for 14 years. She then received a bachelor's degree and a master's degree at the University of Southern California. She also did post-graduate work at U.C. Berkeley and UCLA. She was a special music teacher in the Los Angeles Unified School District for 30 years. She was awarded the Honorary PTA Life Membership, the Life Membership in the Los Angeles City Elementary School Music Association 24th Street Elementary School Award, and the Golden Apple at the 1971 Teacher Remembrance Day Award as Outstanding Teacher.  She was also very active in civic organizations.|~|Mitchell Miles was a wealthy man from Buffalo, NY. He and his brother ran a gambling business, but they were pushed out of Buffalo by the mob. They eventually moved to Los Angeles.|~|Anne Brown was an African American soprano radio and concert singer, perhaps best known for singing the part of Bess in the world premier of Porgy and Bess in Boston. In the late 1940s, Brown moved to Norway, to escape the continuing racial prejudice in the United States.

Summary: Arthur James "Zutty" Singleton was an American jazz drummer. (Wikipedia)|~|Charles Herbert Beal was an American jazz pianist.|~|Louis Daniel Armstrong was an American trumpeter, composer, singer and occasional actor who was one of the most influential figures in jazz. (Wikipedia)|~|George Sylvester "Red" Callender (1916– 1992) was an American string bass and tuba player. He is perhaps best known as a jazz musician, but worked with an array of pop, rock and vocal acts as a member of The Wrecking Crew, a group of first-call session musicians in Los Angeles. (Wikipedia)|~|Arthur Budd Scott was an American jazz guitarist, banjoist and singer. He was one of the earliest musicians associated with the New Orleans jazz scene. As a violinist he performed with James Reese Europe's Clef Club Orchestra at a historic 1912 concert at Carnegie Hall, and the following year worked with Europe's ensemble on the first jazz recordings on the Victor label.|~|Albany Leon "Barney" Bigard (1906–1980) was an American jazz clarinetist known for his 15-year tenure with Duke Ellington. He also played tenor saxophone. (Wikipedia)

Title: Helen Walker's School of Expression, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Helen Walker is seated, 2nd from the left, in a small group of women watching a woman playing the piano. The house is decorated for Christmas.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Helen Walker was a client of attorney Walter L. Gordon, Jr., who had a house in the Sugar Hill district of Los Angeles (also called the W. Adams district). She ran an informal school for young women out of her house, which Gordon referred to as Walker's "School of Expression." Walker was originally born in South Carolina, but moved to Los Angeles in the 1920s. She was the receptionist for Dr. H. H. Towles for over 30 years.

LaMar was a film critic who was published in several newspapers including the Los Angeles Sentinel, the California Eagle and the Los Angeles Times. He had a column titled Through the Keyhole, and he is quoted in several publications on film.|~|Goodwin Knight was a Superior Court Judge in Los Angeles, begining in 1935. He became Lieutenant Governor of California in 1946, was reelected in 1950, and became the Governor of California in 1953 when Earl Warren resigned to become Chief Justice. He was also a pianist.|~|Jessie Graves was actor and member of Hollywood Screen Actor's Guild. He was known for often playing the role of an austere butler.

Name.subject: Hickman, Verna, $d 1908-1990|~|Moore, Marie Johnson, $d 1894-1990|~|Hickman, Paul E., $d 1911-1976|~|Moore, Herman E. (Herman Emmons), $d 1892-1980|~|McMorris, Walter, $d 1899-1975|~|McMorris, Ida Belle, $d 1916-2007

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Judge Herman & Marie Moore, Paul & Verna Hickman, and Walter and Ida McMorris, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Paul E. Hickman was a noted Los Angeles businessman. He was married to Verna Stratton Hickman, who worked for the Golden State Insurance Company.|~|Judge Herman E. Moore, originally from Chicago, served as the U.S. District Judge for the Virgin Islands from 1939-1957.  He was the 2nd African American to serve on the U.S. District Court (the first was William Hastie). Moore was a graduate of Howard University and the Boston University College of Law.  His wife was Marie Johnson Moore.|~|Ida Belle McMorris was married to Walter McMorris.|~|Walter McMorris was a clocker for horse race tracks. He also wrote the column "Mac at the track" for the Oakland Tribune for 25 years.
Description.caption: L to R: Herman Moore, Marie Moore, an Ida McMorris, Walter McMorris (clocker at the Santa Anita racetrack), Verna Hickman, Paul Hickman.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Name.subject: Clark, Horace, $d 1899-1967|~|Miles, Mitchell Bruce, $d 1903-1997|~|Johnson, Josephine D., $d 1912-2008|~|Houston, Edythe A. $q (Edythe Adelaide), $d 1904-1995
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Mabel and Mitchell Miles, Edythe and Norman O. Houston, Josie Pryce, and Horace Clark, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Horace P. Clark, Sr., originally from Mississsippi, graduated from Alcorn College. He relocated to Chicago and became a railroad man. He later moved to Los Angeles where he and his first wife, Vera, built the Clark Hotel.|~|Josie Pryce (Dora Josephine Pryce at birth, Josie Pryce Crawfird in 1940) worked for the Golden State Mutual Insurance Company. She was the sister of Edythe A. Houston.|~|Left to right: unidentified man, Mabel Miles, Mitchell Miles, Edyth Houston, Norman O. Houston, Josie Pryce.|~|Norman O. Houston was one of the first African Americans to earn a varsity letter in football at UC Berkeley. He graduated from UCLA and became an executive with the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company. He was appointed president of the Los Angeles NAACP in 1964.  He participated in the 1965 Selma, Alabama March. He was Deputy Assistant Secretary for Administration, U. S. Department of Health, Education and Welfare during the Nixon adminisatration 1971-1973.|~|Edythe Houston was the wife of Norman Houston, of the Golden State Insurance Company.|~|Mitchell Miles was a wealthy man from Buffalo, NY. He and his brother ran a gambling business, but they were pushed out of Buffalo by the mob. They eventually moved to Los Angeles.

This demonstrates the constantly changing nature of Central Avenue.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.

Title: Mae Johnson and Alyce Key, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Alyce Key is in foreground; Mae Johnson is behind her.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Alyce Key was a Los Angeles dancer turned journalist.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Name.subject: McPherson, Marjorie Eloise, $d 1906-1958|~|King, Celes, $c II, $d 1900-1986|~|King, Leontyne, $d 1905-1976|~|Newman, Robert
Subject: Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Celes King II and Leontyne King dining with a group, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Celes King is seated, 2nd from the left, partially facing away from the photographer. His wife, Leontyne King, is seated facing him, wearing a light-colored outfit. Marjorie McPherson (?) is to the right of Leontyne.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Celes King II (often called "Pop") was born in Houston, Texas, where his father was involved in Harris County's civil rights movement. He moved to Chicago, where he lived during the Depression. There he started a mail order business. (According to his son, "he couldn't find a job, so he made a job!") In 1938 he moved to Los Angeles. He and his uncle, James Nelson, operated the Dunbar Hotel, on Central Avenue -- at the time, the only first class hotel in the city at which African Americans could stay. In the early 1940s, King initiated a boycott against the liquor industry as a protest against the fact that there were no Black liquor salesmen; the boycott continued until the color barrier was broken. His son, Celes King III, was a bail bondsman and political activist in Los Angeles.|~|Leontyne King was a three-term member of the Los Angeles Public Library Commission, and active in a number of business, governmental and community activities. She and her husband Celes King II were influential members of African American society from the 1940s to the 1970s.|~|Marjorie Bright McPherson was married to Dr. Henry McPherson. She was a school administrator.

Johnson was a director at the Conner-Johnson Mortuary.|~|Charles A. Williams is documented as a photographer from Oklahoma, practicing in Los Angeles and married to Yoshi Kuwahara in the 1948 edition of Negro Who's Who in California. It also states that he earned the title "Charles of Avalon" while working at the Avalon Studios, the largest Negro owned studio on the Pacific Coast, and that he had photographed for the Pittsburgh Courier, Pacific Coast Edition; the California Eagle Staff and the Los Angeles Sentinel. His obituary in the Sentinel reports his activities in the public relations profession, ultimately becoming the Chairman of Public Relations International.

Title: Tricky Davis, Alyce Key, Della Miles and Mae Johnson at a show, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Seated, facing the camera, L to R: Tricky Davis, Alyce Key, Della Miles, and Mae Johnson.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Della Miles, long-time resident of Los Angeles, was married to Adolphus Miles.|~|Alyce Key was a Los Angeles dancer turned journalist.|~|Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.|~|C. L. "Tricky" Davis was a popular host and manager at shows and nightclubs, including the Club Broadway and Keyhole Lounge.

Gordon, Jr.|~|Noble Lee Sissle was an African-American jazz composer, lyricist, bandleader, singer, and playwright, best known for the Broadway musical "Shuffle Along" (1921), and its hit song I'm Just Wild About Harry.|~|Dr. N. Curtis King was a physician who founded the Rose Netta Hospital in Los Angeles. It was known for having an interracial staff, and the first interracial blood bank, established by the Red Cross in 1942. Dr. King was also head of the Los Angeles Venereal Clinic and several other clinics.|~|Sonny Howard was a well known "sportsman" (gambler) on Central Avenue.|~|Curtis C. Taylor was a successful   attorney. He earned his law degree at Howard University .|~|Maria Cole was a jazz singer who worked with Count Basie and Duke Ellington, among others. She  married to Nat King Cole in 1948.|~|Paul Leroy "Ox Blood" Howard (1895-1980, Los Angeles) was an American jazz saxophonist and clarinetist.|~|H. H. Towles was a prominent physician and pioneer director of Golden State Mutual Life.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American fashion designers $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Griffin, L'Tanya, $d 1919-1996
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: L'Tanya, fashion designer, 1940s
Description.note: LaTanya (L'Tanya) Griffin inscribed this photo to Walter L. Gordon, Jr.: "To the 'Great One': It is my pleasure knowing you. -- L'Tanya Griffin. At the bottom of the photo, Walter L. Gordon, Jr. has inscribed the photo as "Red Griffin's Pygmalion" (Red Griffin was LaTanya's husband).|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Description.note: L to R: Betty Clark, Ruby Joyce|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Ruby Joyce was a well-known model in Los Angeles.|~|Betty Clark (née Betty Whitfield Wilson), was the wife of Horace Clark . Mrs. Clark, a former fashion designer, had been married to a police officer Arthur Wilson. She divorced Wilson, and later married Horace P. Clark, Sr., proprietor of the Clark Hotel. After his death, she became the full-time manager of the hotel. Betty was also the sister of Mal (Malvin) Whitfield, Olympic track medalist and member of the Tuskegee Airmen who also spent 47 years in Africa training athletes.

Summary: Clarence Muse was an African American vaudevillian, actor, screenwriter, director, composer, and lawyer. Muse was the first African American to "star" in a film. He acted for more than sixty years, and appeared in more than 150 movies.|~|Jack Chase was a West Coast fighter. He was married to actress Lillian Randolph Chase.|~|Lillian Randolph (later Lillian Randolph Chase) was an African American radio, television and film actress, as well as a singer. She was the younger sister of Amanda Randolph (who went on to become an actress). In the 1940s, she and her husband, boxer Jack Chase, purchased a home in the "Sugar Hill" district (West Adams), but could not move in because of restrictive racial covenants. The US Supreme Court declared such covenants unconstitutional in 1948.|~|Willabelle Verble and Clarence Muse were married from 1925 to 1948, when they divorced.

Name.subject: McKinney, Nina Mae, $d 1913-1967|~|Randolph, Lillian, $d 1898-1980
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Lillian Randolph and Nina Mae McKinney in Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Lillian Randolph Chase, an unidentified woman, and Nina Mae McKinney.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Nina Mae McKinney was one of the earliest African American leading actresses. Director King Vidor tapped her for the lead in the 1929 musical Hallelujah; however, during that era, Hollywood was reluctant to showcase African American actresses in leading roles.|~|Lillian Randolph (later Lillian Randolph Chase) was an African American radio, television and film actress, as well as a singer. She was born in Knoxville, Tennessee, the younger sister of Amanda Randolph (who went on to become an actress). Lillian's best known role was the maid Birdie Lee Coggins on the Great Gildersleeve, which began as a radio program and moved to television. In the 1940s, she and her husband, boxer Jack Chase, purchased a home in the "Sugar Hill" district (West Adams), but could not move in because of restrictive racial covenants. The US Supreme Court declared such covenants unconstitutional in 1948.

Name.subject: Hill, Herman, $d 1906-1991|~|Gant, Bess M., $d 1896-1962|~|Fentress, J. Cullen, $d 1910-1989|~|Richardson, Maudelle, $d b. 1912|~|Washington, Chester L.|~|Fentress, Lillian|~|Hill, Gladys, $d b. 1907 or 08|~|Cutler, George M. (George Miles), $d 1901-1949|~|Evans, Lois J., 1913-1986
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Party at photographer George Cutler's house, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Seated on floor (L to R): Lillian Fentress, Chester Washington, Bessie Gant, an unidentified woman, Cullen Fentress. Seated on the couch (L to R): Maudelle Richardson, Gladys Hill, Herman Hill, an unidentified woman, a man identified by his last name "Stubblefield" and an unidentified man. Standing (L to R): an unidentified woman and man, Lois Evans, and George Cutler.|~|George Cutler lived at 2710 Griffith Avenue in 1942.
Summary: Lillian ("Lil") Fentress was active in the Zeta Phi Beta sorority, the YWCA, and in the Los Angeles Elks organization. She was married to J. Cullen Fentress.|~|Gladys Hill, married to Herman Hill, was  active in civic and social clubs including the Kansis City Brunch Club.|~|Bessie M. Gant was a columnist from the Pittsburgh Courier.|~|George Cutler was a commercial photographer.|~|Maudelle Richardson was the wife of H. Leonard Richardson and an avid golfer.|~|Dr. Lois Evans was a chiropodist.|~|Herman Hill was a newspaper reporter and helped to establish the Pittsburg Courier in Los Angeles. He was also the first African American to play varsity basketball at USC.|~|Chester L. Washington became the first African American news employee at the Los Angeles Mirror-News in 1955, and in 1962 he went to work for The Los Angeles Sentinel, where he became editor. He eventually purchased a number of newspapers, becoming the owner of Central News-Wave Publications.|~|J. Cullen Fentress was the owner of Fentress Press, and  served as the founding President of the Western States Golf Association.
Description.caption: Photographer's stamp: Geo. M. Cutler photography

Subject.conceptTopic: Lieutenant governors $z California|~|African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|Political candidates $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American accountants $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Knight, Goodwin, $d 1896-1970|~|Bratton, B. B. $q (Bertrand Ballard), $d 1899-1969|~|Townsend, Vince Monroe, $c Jr., $d 1906-1997
Subject: Government|~|People|~|Legal
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Attorney Vince Monroe Townsend, Jr., candidate for Congress, with B. B. Bratton and Lt. Gov. Goodwin Knight, Los Angeles, 1947 or 1948
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R:  Bertrand B. Bratton, Goodwin Knight, and Vince Monroe Townsend, Jr.
Summary: Vince Monroe Townsend, Jr. was an attorney. Admitted to the California Bar in 1943, he was an advocate for abolishing restrictive covenants for minority groups on real estate in residential areas in the late 1940s. From about 1947 to about 1965, he ran for political office at the city and State levels several times. Affiliated with the Republican Party starting in 1956, he returned to the Democratic Party in 1966.  As of 1966, he was a Los Angeles County public defender. In 1987 he was a judge pro tempore in the Inglewood Municipal Court. Townsend is listed as an actor in three films: Valley of the Head Hunters (1953), Jungle Man-Eaters (1954), and Weird Science (1985).|~|Bratton was a candidate for Los Angeles City Council and had been a member of the Phi Beta Sigma.

Subject.conceptTopic: African American dancers $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Taylor, Nicky|~|Johnson, Mae, $d 1916-1999
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Mae Johnson and Nicky Taylor, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|L to R.: Mae Johnson, Nicky (Micky?) Taylor
Summary: Mae Johnson was a showgirl, dancer, singer and actress who was well known in the black entertainment world in the 1930s and 1940s. Her career began with nightclub performances  in New York. She had the staring role in the film "Keep Punching." On the west coast she appeared in a few Hollywood films that had black musical numbers, giving a memorable performance in Lena Horne's "Stormy Weather." She recorded some songs with Austin McCoy and co-starred in the hit play "Two in a bed" with Louise Beavers.
