Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Beulah Honoré, Leontyne King, Liz McCullough, Harriet Ball and other women, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Gathering of women, including Leontyne King (upper left in light-colored dress and large dark hat), Beulah Honoré (to the right of Leontyne, in a hat with large light-colored flowers), Liz McCullough (center, just below the lamp shade on the left) and Harriet Ball (front row, center in dark dress and dark hat). Front far right: Mabel Scott.
Summary: Liz McCullough came to Los Angeles to visit her boyfriend (he had moved from Chicago to L.A. to start a tombstone business).|~|Leontyne King was a three-term member of the Los Angeles Public Library Commission, and active in a number of business, governmental and community activities. She and her husband Celes King II were influential members of African American society from the 1940s to the 1970s.|~|Mabel Bernice Scott was an American gospel music and R&B vocalist. She arrived on the West Coast blues scene in 1942. Mabel is most remembered for her 1948 hits "Elevator Boogie" and "Boogie Woogie Santa Claus."|~|Beulah Honoré, a former dancer with the Regalettes in Chicago, and also an interior designer and milliner, was married to Gideon Honoré, a member of Duke Ellington's orchestra.

She and her husband Celes King II were influential members of African American society from the 1940s to the 1970s.|~|William B. Williams formed The Charioteers, an African American gospel group. He studied law in his spare time, eventually graduating from Southwest School of Law and becoming an attorney. The women later became business partners in women's clothing. Mrs. Washingon was married to the policeman Roscoe (Rocky) Washington.|~|Hazel Washington was an artist, designer and decorator popular with Hollywood. She was formerly the maid of Hollywood actress Rosalind Russell. The women later became business partners in women's clothing. She also wrote a column for the Chicago Defender titled "This is Hollywood." Mrs. Washingon was married to the policeman Roscoe (Rocky) Washington.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection

Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Hugh MacBeth and Sheriff Eugene Biscailuz, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: MacBeth is the portly gentleman at the far left, and Biscailuz is seated at the desk. The other two individuals in the photograph are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Hugh MacBeth was a Harvard graduate who became part of the first generation of African American lawyers in Los Angeles. With Willis O. Tyler, McBeth helped to organize the Barristers Club as an alternative to the State Bar, which at the time excluded African Americans, Jews, and other ethnic groups.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American models $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Griffin, L'Tanya, $d 1919-1996
Subject: People|~|Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: L'Tanya and another woman modeling swimsuits, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: LaTanya Griffin and an unidentified women are modeling swimsuits at the top of a rocky cliff.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American businesspeople|~|African American fire fighters $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American real estate agents $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Miller, Loren|~|Maddox, Albert, $d 1903-1995|~|Nickerson, William, $c Jr., $d 1879-1945|~|Johnson, Edgar J., $d 1904-2001|~|Cannady, George E., $d 1913-1968|~|Herndon, Bernard C. $q (Bernard Christopher), $d 1902-1959 |~|Howard, H. A. $q (H. Alexander), $d 1900-1972
Subject: Lifestyle|~|Culture
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: African American business and legal figures, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Standing: Bernard Herndon (2nd from left), Al Maddox (5th from left), George Cannady (4th from right), H. A. Howard (3rd from right), Loren Miller (2nd from right), and Edgar Johnson (far right). Seated at far right: William Nickerson.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Bernard C. Herndon who moved to Los Angeles around 1940. He was a real estate broker and president of the non-profit Stovall Foundation for community health and welfare|~|Loren Miller (1903-1967) was an attorney in the 1940s. he later became a California Superior Court Justice in Los Angeles County. Miller was known for his work fighting for equal access to housing and education. He was also the editor of the California Eagle after Charlotta Bass.|~|Edgar J. Johnson rose from agent to president of the Golden State Mutual Insurance Company.|~|(C.) Albert (Al) Maddox founded the Maddox Realty Company, the Maddox Construction Company, was a co-founded Broadway Federal Savings and Loan Association, and the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Golden West Real Estate Board. He also participated in numerous civic organizations and was a lifetime member of the NAACP.|~|George Cannady started out as a firefighter, at a time when African American firefighters were rare. Later he went into the real estate business, and later still he became a lawyer. He died in 1968.|~|William Nickerson Jr. was a prominent Los Angeles-based businessman and founder of Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, which at one time was the largest black-owned business west of the Mississippi.|~|H. A. Howard was a business entrepreneur who founded and was the president of the Broadway Federal Savings and Loan Association. He was very active in civic organizations and was a vice president of the local chapter of the NAACP.

Subject: People|~|Legal
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Police officers Kenneth (Kenny) Harris and Red Davis, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Kenneth Harris is 2nd from the left, and Red Davis is 3rd from the left. The others in the photo are unidentified.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Red (Tom or Tommy) Davis was a well known police officer and athlete on the east side of Los Angeles. Davis was a champion baseball and basketball player at Jefferson, and also played in the Negro leagues during the Depression; later he was the police handball champion 12 times over. Davis and Kenneth (Kenny) Harris attended Wadsworth Elementary school together, and remained friends; as adults they were partners on the police force for many years.|~|Kenneth Harris was a well known police officer and athlete on the east side of Los Angeles. Harris and Red Davis attended Wadsworth Elementary school together, and remained friends; as adults they were partners on the police force for many years.

Title: L'Tanya, Lena Turnham and Louise Franklin, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: LaTanya Griffin (or "L'Tanya," or "L'Tanya Martinique") was a society woman, a model and a fashion designer. In her early twenties, she was awarded a contract by the Guild Studios to design gowns for Ida Lapino.  She was contracted to with the Edward D. Wood Production company to design gowns for 20 of its films in 1954, making her the first African American designer to have a contract with a Hollywood film studio. She and Earl Griffin divorced in 1949.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Louise "Bo" Franklin was a showgirl and dancer who appeared in nightclubs and movies from the 1930s to the 1950s.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African American physicians $z Louisiana $z Shreveport|~|African American physicians $z Washington (D.C.)
Name.subject: McCullough, Liz|~|Gordon, Walter L., $c Jr., $d 1908-2012|~|Goodloe, William Andrew, $d 1894-1973|~|Haddox, Mye, $d 1896-1966|~|Goodloe, Juanita Anne Jones, $d 1915-2016
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Unidentified Woman, William Goodloe, Juanita Goodloe, Walter Gordon, Jr., Liz McCullough, and Mye Haddox in Los Angeles, circa 1951
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr.: "Now these were some hot runners. This man [on left] is Dr. Goodloe, lived in Washington DC. He had a yacht. He was an abortionist; all the congressmen used him. Woman to his right was a similar situation to Ethel [Gordon], on chorus line at Billy Rose’s club. This was a black gal, called high yellow. ... In the middle is me. To the right is Lizzy Putnam (Chicago) [a later interview corrected her name to Liz McCullough]. These are hot flyers. Here’s the disgruntled husband. His name is Mye Hubbard [i.e. Haddox]. He was well known in Shreveport Louisiana. His office must have a photograph section, because people would write me to say they’d seen my photo on his office wall. It was like a clique, we all knew each other. You can look at them and tell they were high rollers. Goodloe got sent to the penitentiary. As a matter of fact, he came out here on a kind of sojourn and when he went back he was supposed to go. This was right before that. This one, look at that chin. His wife… He was a worried husband. Hubbard’s wife, not in photo, she had her own coterie of friends and he didn’t like it. He’s half mad in this photograph, doesn’t like the company he’s keeping. This was taken at my office, I believe. Liz Putnam was just a visitor. Hubbard’s wife left him out here, when he went back he went by himself."|~|Walter Gordon could not remember the name of the woman on the far left, but he represented her when she was arrested by federal authorities for drug possession. He won her case.|~|Left to right: Unidentified woman, Dr. William A. Goodloe, Juanita Goodloe, Walter Gordon, Jr., Liz McCullough, Mye Haddox.
Summary: Mrs.Juanita Goodloe was the wife of Dr. William A. Goodloe. She was an ex-chorus girl with Ethel Sissle Gordon, Walter L. Gordon, Jr.'s wife.|~|Dr. William Goodloe was a physician from Washington D.C. who later served more than 2 years in prison for performing an abortion, as well as obstructing justice and bribery charges.|~|Walter L. Gordon, Jr. was an African American attorney in Los Angeles.|~|Mye Haddox was a physician from Shreveport, Louisiana.|~|Liz McCullough came to Los Angeles to visit her boyfriend (he had moved from Chicago to L.A. to start a tombstone business).

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American women $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Clark, Betty Whitfield Wilson, $d 1912 or 13-1998
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Betty Clark, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Betty Clark (née Betty Whitfield Wilson), was the wife of Horace Clark . Mrs. Clark, a former fashion designer, had been married to a police officer Arthur Wilson. She divorced Wilson, and later married Horace P. Clark, Sr., proprietor of the Clark Hotel. After his death, she became the full-time manager of the hotel. Betty was also the sister of Mal (Malvin) Whitfield, Olympic track medalist and member of the Tuskegee Airmen who also spent 47 years in Africa training athletes.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Funeral program for Jesse B. Mann, Chicago, October 1988
Description.note: Funeral took place in Cage Memorial Chapel, Chicago and interment took place at Burr Oak Cemetery, Chicago.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Jesse Bowman Mann was born on September 3, 1913 in Greenville, MS. He relocated to Chicago when he was a child and went to college at Howard University and studied law at Northwestern University. He practiced law in Chicago for almost fifty years. He was also a member of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American musicians
Name.subject: Ramsey, George A. $q (George Alvetta), $d 1889-1963  |~|Garner, George, $d 1892-1971|~|Hogue, Lilly T., $d 1889-1977|~|McNeil, Albert|~|Peters, Cortez|~|Orticke, Lester Lionel, $d 1922-1966|~|Clark, Horace Pettibone, $c Jr., $d 1919-1997|~|Williams, H. Hamilton, $d 1911-1981|~|Richards, Eleanor|~|Williams, Charles Henry, $d d. 1966|~|Kelly, Cleveland|~|Porter, Blanche|~|Harriel, Gwendolyn C. Becks, $d 1923-1952|~|Miller, Walter|~|Peters, Lillian|~|National Association of Negro Musicians (U.S.)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Planning commissioners for the National Association of Negro Musicians, Los Angeles, 1949
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Photograph appeares in the Los Angeles Sentinel, "Plan National Musicians Convention," 3 Mar.: 1949, A2
Summary: Cortez W. Peters, Sr., opened a business and vocational institute to fully prepare African Americans for business and civil service employment. The first school was in Washington, D.C., and others opened in Baltimore and Chicago.|~|Gwendolyn Harriel was a leading soloist at Independent church.|~|George Garner was a tenor vocalist (and first African American to sing with the Chicago Symphony Orchestry) and conductor.|~|Dr. H. Hamilton Williams was a biologist, horticulturalist and landscape architect. Head of the department of ornamental horticulture and the Hampton Institute in 1944, he completed a Ph.D. degree in ornamental horticulture at Cornell University in the same year. He may have been working in Los Angeles by 1949, and was employed as a biologist in turf grass reaearch and education at the Los Angeles County Arboretum up to at least 1970. While at Cornell, he directed the Southside Commmunity Chorus. He was also an organist.|~|Andrew Sturgeon "Doc" Young was an American sports journalist and author. He was also one of the first African American publicists working in Hollywood. He graduated from Hampton Institute (now Hampton Univeristy) in 1941 with a BA degree in business administration, where he edited the school newspaper.   Throughout his career he received numerous honors from the National Newspaper Publishers Association. In the 1950s, he served in several top editorial positions at Jet Magazine and Ebony Magazine. He also worked in editorial positions at the Los Angeles Sentinel and the Chicago Defender.|~|George Ramsey was a San Diego businessman, and proprietor of the Douglass Hotel, opened in 1924 as a place for both entertainment and lodging for African Americans in San Diego. He also ran a racetrack in Tijuana with his brothers.|~|Albet J. MCneil (b. 1920) is an American choral conductor, ethnomusicologist, author, and founder of the Albert McNeil Jubilee Singers. His career has been dedicated to upholding choral music traditions with the presentation of Negro spirituals and concert music by African American composers. He is Professor Emeritus of Music at the University of California, Davis, where he was director of choral activities and headed the Music Education Program. (Wikipedia)
Description.caption: Text from newspaper caption: Commissioners confer -- The Central Colony of the LosAngeles Planning Commissioners for the National Association of Negro Musicians, Inc., met at a dinner meeting here last Friday night. Plans for the annual musicians convention, slated for Los Angles August 21-26, were discussed. Shown above seated. left to right, are: Mrs. Evelyn Williams, Cleveland Kelly, Mrs. Lilly T. Hogue, Albert McNeil, state organizer; Mrs. Lillian Peters, Washington, D.C.; Walter Miller, and Mrs. Blanche Porter. Standing, starting at the left are Charles Williams, Horace Pettibone Clark, Jr., George Ramsey, of San Diego; Miss Gwendolyn Herriel, Cortez peters, Washington, D.C.' Rev. George Garner, regional director; Dr. H. Hamilton Williams, Miss Eleanor Richards, secretary local branch; "Doc" Young, Sentinel sports editor, and Hester Orticke. [The person identified as Hester Orticke is a man, and is possibly Lester Lionel Orticke, who lived in Los Angeles at this time.]

Subject: Entertainment|~|Lifestyle|~|People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Esvan Mosby dancing with female partner, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: Esvan Mosby and an unidentified African American woman in a dance performance.|~|Backside of the photograph mentions the name Richard Tucker (tenor, Metropolitan Opera House?) and the address 26 Lime St., Boston.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Esvan Mosby was a well-known African American dancer who danced at New York's Cotton Club and the Apollo Theater in the 1930s and 1940s. He also owned several nightclubs on Central Avenue in Los Angeles after World War II, and was sometimes called the "Mayor of Central Avenue." He died in 1986.

Name.subject: Knight, Goodwin, $d 1896-1970|~|Bratton, B. B. $q (Bertrand Ballard), $d 1899-1969|~|Townsend, Vince Monroe, $c Jr., $d 1906-1997|~|Graves, Jesse, $d 1879-1949|~|Johnson, Ivan J., $c III, $d 1903-1975
Subject: People|~|Legal
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Attorney Ivan Johnson addressing an audience, Los Angeles, 1940s
Description.note: L to R: Jessie Graves, B. B. Bratton, an unidentified man (at rear), Goodwin Knight, Ivan Johnson, unidentified woman (at rear), Vince Townsend.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Summary: Bratton was a candidate for Los Angeles City Council and had been a member of the Phi Beta Sigma.|~|Following a career as a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles, Goodwin (Goodie) Jess Knight was Lieutenant Governor of California from 1946 to 1953, and Governor of California from 1953 to 1959.|~|Ivan J. Johnson III was a Los Angeles attorney. He was one of the first African Americans to letter in track at USC and UC Berkeley. He was a charter member of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity. Shortly before his death, he was honored by the Langston Law Club as the dean of  local attorneys.|~|Jessie Graves was actor and member of Hollywood Screen Actor's Guild. He was known for often playing the role of an austere butler.|~|Vince Monroe Townsend, Jr. was an attorney. Admitted to the California Bar in 1943, he was an advocate for abolishing restrictive covenants for minority groups on real estate in residential areas in the late 1940s. From about 1947 to about 1965, he ran for political office at the city and State levels several times. Affiliated with the Republican Party starting in 1956, he returned to the Democratic Party in 1966.  As of 1966, he was a Los Angeles County public defender. In 1987 he was a judge pro tempore in the Inglewood Municipal Court. Townsend is listed as an actor in three films: Valley of the Head Hunters (1953), Jungle Man-Eaters (1954), and Weird Science (1985).

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American businesspeople $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Houston, Arthur, $c Jr. |~|Spurlock, Herman
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: DUP to #112? (Arthur Houston and Herman Spurlock at a social gathering, Los Angeles, 1940s)
Description.note: DUPLICATE TO 112?|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|Arthur Houston, seated on the floor at the far left, started out with a small barbershop and pool hall, and later became a licensed real estate broker, contractor and building inspector. He also opened the Crescent Insurance Agency and the Crescent Real Estate and Mortgage company. He was active in the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity, and participated in anti-segregation efforts in Los Angeles and neighboring areas. Herman Spurlock, well known on Central Avenue, made a living putting together shows and entertainment for nightclubs and fundraisers. He is seated on the floor, second from the right. The rest of the people in the photograph are unidentified, although one of the women may have been Augustus Hawkins' secretary.

He choreographed the Broadway productions "Africana" and "Miss Calico," in which Ethel Waters performed. He also sang and danced with Sophie Tucker. Dancer managed the Ebony Club in the Dunbar Hotel in the 1930s.|~|Beulah Honoré was married to Gideon Honore, a member of Duke Ellington's orchestra.|~|Madeline Green was a "songbird," a singer who worked with Earl 'Fatha' Hines, Count Basie, and Lionel Hampton. Subject.conceptTopic: African American lawyers--California--Los Angeles|~|African Americans $x Rites and ceremonies|~|Baptists $x Customs and practices|~|African American clergy $z California $z Riverside
Name.subject: Gordon, Walter L.|~|Moss, L. B. $q (Leander Bonaparte), $c Rev., $d 1899-1986
Subject: Media
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Poster for the First Annual Baptist Hour Program, Shrine Auditorium, Los Angeles, May 30, 1954
Description.note: Various Baptist churches sponsored a "Baptist hour" at the Shrine Auditorium on Sunday, May 30, 1954, which included the Unity Chorale Chorus (made up of choir members from many different churches). The principal speaker was the Reverend L. B. Moss (in some news stories he is identified as L. W. Moss), and Walter L. Gordon, Jr. was the MC for the event.|~|All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.
Description.caption: First annual Baptist Hour Program, depicting the progress of the Baptist Church. Featuring the Unity Choral Chorus, composed of a united group of Baptist churches. Directors: Rev. K. D. Friend, Mrs. Eleanor Survine; Mr. H. P. Markham. Guest speaker Dr. L.B. Moss, Pres. of the Calif. State Baptist Convention, Trustee of Bishop College. Master of Ceremoney att'y Walter L. Gordon, candidate for 62nd Assembly District. Shrine Auditorium, Jefferson and Royal Street, Sun. May 30, 3:00 p.m. Sponsored by churches in the Calif. State Baptist Convention. Donation $1.25 in advance. On sale at West Coast Ticket Agency, 4233 Central Ave., AD 1-3751. West Los Angeles Gospel Music Salon, 1548 W. Jefferson, RE 2-5437.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
Subject.conceptTopic: African American singers|~|Tap dancers $z United States
Name.subject: Reed, Leonard|~|Horne, Lena
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: YRLSC_gordonphotos_1018 [Lena Horne and Leonard Reed, Los Angeles, 1940s]
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|[Lena Horne and Leonard Reed, with an unidentified man and woman behind them]
Summary: Lena Horne was an American jazz and pop singer, dancer and actress, and civil rights activist.|~|Leonard Reed was a an American tap dancer. With his partner, Willie Bryant, he created the Shim Sham Shimmy tap dance routine.
Description.caption: Inscribed: Leonard Reed

Title: YRLSC_gordonphotos_1020 [Sportsmen sitting at a table, Los Angeles, 1940s]
Description.note: All information concerning the content and description of the image was provided by Walter Gordon.|~|[Ernest Bendy (Dynamite Jackson) at the head of the table; Herman Hill to the right of Jackson; Eddie Burbridge half-visible, first fro the right; Hally Harding, second from the right. Commenting on another photograph of the same gathering, Mr. Gordon stated that the men at the table either played sports or were sports writers.]
Summary: Dynamite Jackson (Ernest Bendy) was a boxer who won the Heavyweight Championship of California on June 23,  1931.
Description.caption: Ernest Bendy - Dynamite Jackson / Herman Hill / Hally Harding

Subject.conceptTopic: African American fashion designers $z California $z Los Angeles|~|African American models $z California $z Los Angeles
Name.subject: Joyce, Ruby|~|Clark, Betty Whitfield Wilson, $d 1912 or 13-1998
Subject: People
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Betty Clark and Ruby Joyce, Los Angeles
Description.note: L to R: Betty Clark, Ruby Joyce
Summary: Ruby Joyce was a well-known model in Los Angeles.|~|Betty Clark (née Betty Whitfield Wilson) , was the wife of Horace Clark. Mrs. Clark, a former fashion designer, has been married to a police officer Arthur Wilson. She divorced Wilson, and later married Horace P. Clark, Sr., proprietor of the Clark Hotel. After his death, she became the full-time manager of the hotel. Betty was also the sister of Mal (Malvin) Whitfield, Olympic track medalist and member of the Tuskegee Airmen who also spent 47 years in Africa training athletes.

Project Name: Gordon (Walter L.) and William C. Beverly, Jr. Collection
